notice need not be given.

Where he draws solely for the purpose of raising money by discount for himself, he expects to pay the bill, and there is no person to whom he can resort for repayment. There is no person on whom he can have a legal or an equitable demand, in consequence of the non-payment of the bill. But how can the same reasoning be said to apply a fortiori to the case of the bill being drawn for the use of the acceptor? In such case the relative situation of the parties must be substantially the same as if the money raised on the bill for the acceptor, were funds of the drawer in his hands, on which the bill was drawn. Every motive for requiring notice of non-payment, in the case of a bill drawn upon funds, except that which results from a right to claim those funds by a suit, would apply to a bill drawn to raise money for the acceptor, unless it was understood at the time that the acceptor was not to pay the bill.

The case of Warwyn v. St. Quintin, then, can only be supported on the idea of an understanding that the drawee was not to pay the bill, or that a bill, drawn, not in the usual course of business, is a transaction to which commercial rules do not apply.

column3: as follows:

column1: This case differs from that of Rose v. Himely in one material fact. The vessel and cargo
column2: which constitute the subject of controversy
column3: were seized within the territorial jurisdiction of the government of St. Domingo
column4: and carried into a Spanish port. While lying in that port
column5: proceedings were regularly instituted in the court for the island of Guadaloupe
column6: the cargo was sold by a provisional order of that court
column7: after which the vessel and cargo were condemned. The single question
column8: therefore
column9: which exists in this case is
column10: did the court of the captor lose its jurisdiction over the captured vessel by its being carried into a Spanish port.

column1: *294 The seizure was indisputably a valid seizure
column2: and vested the lawful possession of the vessel in the sovereign of the captor. The right consequently existed in full force to apply immediately to the proper tribunals for an examination of
column3: and decision on the offence alleged to have been committed. The jurisdiction of those tribunals had attached
column4: and this right to decide upon the offence was complete.

column1: When a seizure is thus made for the violation of a municipal law
column2: the mode of proceeding must be exclusively regulated by the sovereign power of the country
column3: and no foreign court is at liberty to question the correctness of what is done
column4: unless the court passing the sentence loses its jurisdiction by some circumstance which the law of nations can notice. Recapture
column5: escape
column6: or a voluntary discharge of the captured vessel would be such a circumstance
column7: because the sovereign would be thereby deprived of the possession of the thing
column8: and of his power over it. While this possession remains
column9: the res may be either restored or sold
column10: the sentence of the court can be executed
column11: and therefore this possession seems to be the essential fact on which the jurisdiction of the court depends.

column1: The laws of the United States require that a vessel which has been seized for violating them should be tried in the district where the offence is committed
column2: and certainly it would be irregular and illegal for the tribunal of a different district to act upon the case. But of this irregularity
column3: it is believed
column4: no foreign court could take notice. The United States might enable the admiralty courts of one district to decide on captures made for offences committed in another district. It is an internal regulation
column5: to be expounded by our own courts
column6: and of which the law of nations can take no notice. The possession of the thing would be in the sovereign power of the state
column7: and it is competent to that power to give jurisdiction over it to any of its tribunals. There exists a full power over the subject
column8: and an ability to execute the sentence of the court. The sovereign power possessing jurisdiction over the thing
column9: must be presumed by foreign tribunals to have exercised that jurisdiction properly. But if the res be out of the power of the sovereign
column10: he cannot act upon it
column11: nor delegate authority to act upon it to his courts.

column1: *295 If these principles be correct
column2: it remains to inquire whether the brig Sea Flower remained in the possession and in the power of the sovereign of the captor after being carried into a Spanish port.

column1: Had this been a prize of war
column2: we have precedents and principles which would guide us. The cases cited from Robinson's Reports
column3: and the regulations made by Louis XVI. in November
column5: show that the practice of condemning prizes of war while lying in neutral ports has prevailed in England
column6: and has been adopted in France. The objections to this practice may perhaps be sufficient to induce nations to change it by common consent
column7: but until they change it the practice must be submitted to
column8: and the sentence of condemnation passed under such circumstances will bind the property
column9: unless the legislature of the country in which the captured vessel may be claimed
column10: or the law of nations
column11: shall otherwise direct.

column1: The sovereign whose officer has in his name captured a vessel as prize of war
column2: remains in possession of that vessel
column3: and has full power over her
column4: so long as she is in a situation in which that possession cannot be rightfully divested. The fact whether she is an enemy vessel or not ought however to be judicially inquired into and decided
column5: and therefore the property in a neutral captured as an enemy is never changed until sentence of condemnation has passed; and the practice of nations requires that the vessel shall be in a place of safety before such sentence can be rendered. In the port of a neutral she is in a place of safety
column6: and the possession of the captor cannot be lawfully divested
column7: because the neutral sovereign
column8: by himself or by his courts
column9: can take no cognizance of the question of prize or no prize. This position is not intended to apply to the case of a sovereign bound by particular treaties to one of the belligerents; it is intended to apply only to those neutrals who are free to act according to the general law of nations. In such case the neutral sovereign cannot wrest from the possession of the captor a prize of war brought into his ports.

column1: A vessel captured as prize of war is then
column2: while lying in the port of a neutral
column3: still in the possession of the sovereign *296 of the captor
column4: and that possession cannot be rightfully divested.

column1: It is objected that his courts can take no jurisdiction of a vessel under such circumstances
column2: because they cannot enforce a sentence of restitution.

column1: But it is to be recollected that the possession of the captor is in principle the possession of his sovereign; he is commissioned to seize in the name of the sovereign
column2: and is as much an officer appointed for that purpose
column3: as one who in the body of a county serves a civil process. He is under the controul and direction of the sovereign
column4: and must be considered as ready to obey his commands legally communicated through his courts.

column1: It is true that in point of fact cruisers are often commanded by men who do not feel a due respect for the laws
column2: and who are not of sufficient responsibility to compensate the injuries their improper conduct may occasion; but in principle they must be considered as officers commissioned by their sovereign to make a seizure in the particular case
column3: and to be ready to obey the legitimate mandate of the sovereign directing a restitution. The property therefore may be restored while lying in a neutral port
column4: and whether it may or may not be sold in the neutral port
column5: the condemnation without a sale may change the property
column6: if such condemnation be valid.

column2: then
column3: the difficulty of executing the sentence does not seem to afford any conclusive argument against the jurisdiction of the court of the captor over a vessel in possession of the captor
column4: but lying in a neutral or friendly port.

column1: Do the same principles apply to a seizure made within the territory of a state for the violation of its municipal laws?
In the solution of this question the court can derive no aid from precedent. The case perhaps has only occurred in the wars which have been carried on since the year 1793

and on this plea issue was joined. At the trial of the cause, the avowant gave in evidence a lease for one year certain, and a subsequent possession for two years. On motion to instruct the jury that this lease did not support the avowrv, the court said, that if the jury should be of opinion that the subsequent possession was under the original contract, and without any new agreement, then the avowant was entitled to recover, otherwise not. The jury found a verdict for the avowant.

The lease stated in the avowry is obviously a different lease from that which was given in evidence. A lease for three years is not a lease for one year. But it is contended that a subsequent possession, without any new express agreement, amounts to an extension of the original lease, and for this Bacon's Abridgment, and a dictum of Judge Buller, in the case of Birch v. Wright, 1 Term, 378. have been cited. But those cases do not prove the point they were supposed to establish. In those cases, the original terms of the lease admit of the extension which was afterwards made, by consent of parties. The lease was made for one year, and afterwards from year to year, as long as both parties should please. The principle of continuance is introduced into the original contract, and the occupation for three years is evidence that the circumstance had occurred, by force of which, the contract should be a lease for three years. But in this case the original contract contains no principle of continuance. It is for a limited time, and can only be extended by a new contract, either express or implied. The lease, therefore, offered in evidence, does not support the avowry. But a question on which the court has felt more difficulty, is this: Does the plea admit the demise, or is the avowant bound to prove it? If the plea admits the demise, then, notwithstanding the variance, the verdict is right, and *303 the court has not erred in that part of the opinion which is against the party taking the exception.

column1: 8 U.S. 317
2 L. Ed. 633

THE MAYOR AND COMMONALTY OF ALEXANDRIA
v.
PATTEN AND OTHERS.
ERROR to the circuit court of the district of Columbia
column2: sitting at Alexandria
column3: in an action of debt brought by the mayor and commonalty of Alexandria
column4: for the use of John G. Ladd
column5: against Thomas Patten and his sureties
column6: on a bond given for the performance of his duty as vendue-master.

column1: The object of the suit was to recover a sum of money alleged to remain in his hands as vendue-master on account of goods sold for Ladd. Patten was also the debtor of Ladd for goods sold by him to Patten
column2: who gave in evidence payments which exceeded the amount due upon the latter account
column3: and which
column4: if applied to the former account
column5: would nearly
column6: if not entirely
column7: discharge that debt. The payments were attended by circumstances which the defendants considered as evidence of a clear intention to apply them to the debt due from Patten as vendue-master; 'Whereupon the counsel for the plaintiffs prayed the opinion of the court whether
column8: from the manner in which the payments were made as aforesaid
column9: the said John G. Ladd had not a right to apply so much of the money
column10: paid to him as aforesaid
column11: as would discharge the debt due to him as aforesaid
column12: for goods sold as aforesaid to the said Thomas Patten
column13: to the discharge of the same. Whereupon the court instructed the jury
column14: that if they should be satisfied by the evidence that the payments of the money by the defendant Patten were made on account of the goods sold at vendue
column15: and so understood by both parties at the time of the payments
column16: they must be applied to that account.

column2: at the time of paying the money
column3: did not direct to which account it should be applied
column4: and if it was not understood by the parties at the time of payment on which account it was made
column5: the plaintiff had a right immediately to make the application to which account he pleased; but such application must have been recent
column6: and before any alteration had taken place in the circumstances of Mr. Patten.

column1: 'If neither of the parties made the application as aforesaid
column2: and if the parties did not then understand on which account it was made
column3: then the payments ought in law to be applied to the discharge of the vendue account
column4: the non-payment of which is alleged as the breach of the bond upon which the present suit is brought.'

column1: To this opinion the plaintiffs excepted
column2: and the verdict and judgment being against them
column3: brought their writ of error

column2: for plaintiffs in error
column3: contended that where there are different debts due by a debtor to his creditor
column4: and a payment be made generally on account
column5: the creditor has a right to apply the payment
column6: whenever he pleases
column7: to which account he pleases
column8: and cited the case of Goddard v. Cox

column2: contra.

column1: It is admitted that the defendant had the right at the time of payment to direct its application
column2: and that if he did not then exercise that right
column3: it devolved upon the plaintiff. But the question is
column4: when is the plaintiff to exercise the right? Can he
column5: at any indefinite period after the payment
column6: and under any change of circumstances
column7: apply the payment as he pleases? Can he
column8: at the moment of trial
column9: when the defendant produces evidence of payments
column10: say I choose to apply these payments to the other account? The rules of law are all founded in reason. Some reasonable limit must be supposed to the exercise of this right. In the present case the interests of third persons are involved. The sureties may have been lulled into security by the evidence of these payments.

column1: The court below was bound to decide according to the laws of Virginia
column2: which have been adopted by congress for the government of the county of Alexandria.

column1: The law is conclusively settled in Virginia
column2: by the highest tribunal in that state
column3: in the case of Braxton v. Southerland
column4: 1 Wash. 133. where the president of the court of appeals
column5: in delivering the opinion of the court
column6: says
column7: 'Although
column8: if the debtor neglect to make the application at the time of payment
column9: the election is then cast upon the creditor
column10: yet it is incumbent upon the latter
column11: in such a case
column12: to make a recent application
column13: by entries in books or papers
column14: and not to keep parties and securities in suspense
column15: changing their situation from time to time
column16: as his interest
column17: governed by events
column18: might dictate.' And upon this principle the decree of the court in that case was founded. It was not a mere dictum
column19: but the very ground of the court's decision. This then being the law of Virginia
column20: the court below was bound by it.

column1: If the opinion of the court of appeals of Virginia needed support
column2: it would be found in 2 Pothier on Obligations
column3: 45. who gives it as a rule of the civil law
column4: that 'when the debtor in paying makes no application
column5: the creditor to whom money is due for different causes may apply it to the discharge of which he pleases.' But he goes on to say
column6: 'It is necessary
column7: 1st. That this application should have been made at the time; and
column8: 2d. That the application which the creditor makes should be equitable.' Another rule
column9: in p. 49. is
column10: that 'when the application has not been made either by the debtor or the creditor
column11: the application ought to be made to that debt which the debtor had
column12: at the time
column13: most interest to discharge.' And
column14: as a corollary
column15: he says
column16: 'The application is made rather to the debt for which the debtor has given a surety
column17: than to those which he owes alone. The reason is
column18: that in paying the former he discharges himself towards two creditors—his principal creditor
column19: and his surety whom he is bound to indemnify.'These principles are confirmed by 1 Domat. 287. tit. de solutione.

column2: cited for the plaintiffs
column3: is a mere Nisi Prius case before Chief Justice Lee
column4: in Middlesex; and it only decides the principle
column5: that where a defendant is indebted to the plaintiff on two simple contracts of equal dignity and of the same nature
column6: and for neither of which is any other person bound
column7: and the payment is made generally on account
column8: without any application having been made by the defendant
column9: the right to make the application devolves on the plaintiff. It does not decide the question now before the court
column10: which is
column11: whether the plaintiff is not bound to make a recent application in cases where the interests of sureties are concerned.

column1: All the cases in which the plaintiff has been permitted at law to make his election
column2: are cases where the debts were of equal dignity and of similar nature
column3: and where it did not appear to be important to the debtor
column4: or any other person
column5: to which debt the payment should be applied. Esp. N. P. 229.

column2: in truth
column3: no difference in principle between the rule in equity and the rule at law
column4: as to the application of payments.

column2: Ch. J. after stating the case
column3: delivered the opinion of the court
column4: as follows:

column1: It is a clear principle of law
column2: that a person owing money on two several accounts
column3: as upon bond and simple contract
column4: may elect to apply his payments to which account he pleases; but if he fails to make the application
column5: the election passes from him to the creditor. No principle is recollected which obliges the creditor to make this election immediately. After having made it he is bound by it
column6: but until he makes it he is free to credit either the bond or simple contract.

column2: circumstances may occur
column3: and perhaps did occur in this case
column4: which would be equivalent to the declaration of his election on the part of the debtor
column5: and therefore the court was correct in instructing the jury
column6: that if they should be satisfied that the payments were understood to be made on account of the goods sold at vendue
column7: they ought to apply them to the discharge of that account; but in declaring that the election
column8: which they supposed to devolve on the plaintiff if the application of the money was not understood at the time by the parties
column9: was lost if not immediately exercised
column10: that court erred.

column2: therefore
column3: must be reversed
column4: and the cause remanded for a new trial.

column1: 8 U.S. 324

THIS was a writ of error to a supposed judgment of the circuit court of the district of Columbia
column2: for the county of Washington
column3: between Hodgson and Thompson
column4: plaintiffs
column5: and Jacob Mountz
column6: John Mountz and Henry Knowles

column1: Hodgson and Thompson had recovered judgment in the court below
column2: at December term
column4: against Jacob Mountz and George Reintzel. By the act of assembly of Maryland
column5: 1791. c. 67. entitled 'an act for regulating the mode of staying execution
column6: and for repealing the acts of assembly therein mentioned
column7: ' it is enacted
column8: that no execution shall issue upon any judgment
column9: provided the person or persons against whom such judgment is obtained
column10: shall come before two justices of the peace of the county
column11: where such person or persons shall reside
column12: within two months after the rendition of such judgment
column13: and together with two other persons
column14: such as the said justices shall approve of
column15: and confess judgment for his debt and costs of suit adjudged
column16: with stay of execution for six months thereafter; which confession shall be made in manner and form following
column17: that is to say 'you H. M. A. B. and C. D. do confess judgment to E. F.' &c. which confession shall be signed by the justices before whom the same is made
column18: and a certificate thereof shall be procured under the hands of the said justices
column19: and such certificate shall be a sufficient supersedeas to the sheriff to forbear serving execution upon the body or goods of the person so obtaining such certificate. And it is further enacted
column20: that the justices shall return the confession of judgment to the clerk of the court
column21: where the first judgment was rendered
column22: by the next court in course
column23: to be entered on record; and after the expiration of the time limited in such confession
column24: it shall be lawful to take out execution thereon
column25: without a scire facias or any other delay
column26: against either the principal or the security
column27: or all or either of them for such judgment so confessed.

column1: According to the provisions of this act
column2: the original defendant jacob Mountz (without his co-defendant George Reintzel) went before John Ott and Daniel Reintzel
column3: and
column4: together with Henry Knowles and John Mountz
column5: his sureties
column6: confessed judgment to Hodgson and Thompson
column7: in the form prescribed by the act of assembly. John Ott was admitted to be a justice of peace of the county of Washington
column8: but Daniel Reintzel signed his name as Mayor of Georgetown.

column1: By the act of assembly of Maryland
column2: 1789. c. 23. incorporating the town of Georgetown
column3: it is enacted 'that the mayor
column4: recorder and aldermen' 'shall be justices of the peace within the said town
column5: and the precincts thereof
column6: ' and that each of them 'shall have the same jurisdiction as to debts
column7: as any justice of the peace of any county of this state now hath
column8: or shall hereafter have by law.'

column1: After the expiration of the six month mentioned in the confession of judgment
column2: a ca. sa. was issued thereon
column3: against Jacob Mountz
column4: Henry Knowles
column5: and John Mountz
column6: upon which they were all taken
column7: and on the return thereof
column8: they moved to quash the execution;

column1: 1. Because the confession of judgment was not before two justices of peace of the county; and
2. Because the judgment was not confessed by George Reintzel
column2: the co-defendant in the first judgment.

column1: But the court below overruled both objections
column2: and refused to quash the execution; whereupon the defendants took a bill of exceptions
column3: and brought their writ of error.

column2: for the plaintiffs in error
contended
column3: that Daniel Reintzel was not a justice of peace of the county
column4: but only of Georgetown. That he had only the powers necessary for the preservation of the peace in that town. And even if he had power within the town to receive a confession of judgment
column5: it did not appear by the record that this confession was taken in the town
column6: but might have been taken elsewhere
column7: in which case his act would be void.

column2: they contended that all the defendants to the original judgment
column3: must join in the supersedeas. The words of the act are
column4: 'such person or persons
column5: ' thereby implying that if there were several defendants
column6: all must join. Suppose there should be five solvent defendants
column7: and one insolvent who supersedes the judgment with two sureties; the plaintiff cannot take out execution against the five
column8: until the expiration of the six months. If execution be stayed as to one
column9: it is stayed as to all. The execution on a joint judgment must be against all; it must follow the nature of the judgment.

column2: contra.

column1: This is an ex parte proceeding by the debtor. He chuses the magistrates before whom he will confess the judgment; he is estopped to deny their jurisdiction
column2: after he has had the benefit of the delay. But if this be an error
column3: it is an error of fact which this court cannot correct. It is a question of fact
column4: whether Daniel Reintzel be a justice of peace of the county. He has signed his name as mayor
column5: yet he may also be a justice of peace of the county. They might as well assert that John Ott is not a justice of peace
column6: because he has not signed his name as such. There is no such office as that of a justice of peace of Georgetown. It is to be presumed that the confession was made in Georgetown
column7: as the contrary does not appear
column8: and Mr. Reintzel signed his name in his official character as mayor of that town.

column1: The writ of error complains of the judgment of the two justices
column2: not of that of the circuit court. Or rather the error which they assign is an error in the judgment of the justices
column3: and not in the judgment of the court.

column1: The confession of judgment only stays the service of the execution
column2: it does not prevent its emanation. The words of the act are
column3: that it shall be a sufficient supersedeas to the sheriff to forbear serving execution. The execution may issue against all
column4: but shall not be served upon him who has confessed judgment with sureties.

column1: The judgment confessed before the justices
column2: by being returned to the office of the clerk of the circuit court
column3: and there entered of record
column4: becomes a judgment of that court; otherwise no scire facias could lie to revive the judgment.

column1: The act of assembly makes the confession of the second judgment a complete supersedeas to the first. No execution can issue on the first judgment after confession of the second. The words of the act are positive. 'No execution shall issue.' &c.

column2: Ch. J.

column1: The majority of the court is of opinion that the writ of error must be quashed
column2: this court not having jurisdiction.

column1: The refusal of the court below
column2: to quash the execution on motion
column3: is by some of the judges supposed not to be a judgment to which a writ of error will lie. Others are of opinion that a writ of error will lie to that decision of the court
column4: but that this writ of error is not to the judgment of the circuit court
column5: but to that of the justices.

column2: that the first bottomry bond was given by the master to Blaine

column4: and that the consideration of that bond consisted of money paid to take up a prior bottomry bond and given to one Robertson

column1: The hypothecation in London was a legal lien upon she ship
column2: and no circumstance had occurred to deprive the libellant of its benefit. Possession of the vessel hypothecated
column3: is never delivered to the obligee of a bottomry bond; so that no inference of fraud can be drawn from the fact
column4: that the possession remained with the obligor: nor was there any rule of law which required the obligee to assert his lien in any given time. This lien was prior to that of the judgment creditors.

column3: given by the owner in Virginia

column5: on bottomry

column7: and hypothecate the ship therefor. Cro. Jac. 209. Sharpley v. Hurrel
column8: 2 Bl. Com. 458. A master
column9: if part owner
column10: may take up money on bottomry to the value of his own share
column11: in places where the owners reside. 2 <i>Molloy
column13: and 15. Hence it may be inferred that any other owner may do the like. If the master may hypothecate the ship a fortiori may the owner. Park
column14: 410. The executions of Donald and Burton were void

column2: for the defendants in error

column1: 1st. With regard to the freights

column3: as there was no application at the time of the receipt of them

column1: The libel in this case was filed upon two instruments of writing purporting to be bottomry bonds

column1: The voyage in the former bond terminated in Virginia

column3: and the vessel has since made a voyage to this country. Upon her return here
column4: and before the warrant of the admiralty was served

column1: The ship has been sold under the order of the court below
column2: and the question is
column3: who has the preferable claim to the money now lying in the marshal's hands. On the validity of the bond of the master there can be no question. It is acknowledged by counsel to possess all the requisites of a good bottomry bond. But it was contended that it was satisfied by the freights
column4: which it appears Blaine was in the receipt of; and if not satisfied

column8: on the nature and effect of the contract of bottomry.

column1: A bottomry bond made by the master vests no absolute indefeasible interest in the ship on which it is founded
column2: but gives a claim upon her which may be enforced with all the expedition and efficiency of the admiralty process. This rule is expressly laid down in the books
column3: and will be found consistent with the principle of the civil law
column4: upon which the contract of bottomry is held to give a claim upon the ship. In the case of a bottomry bond executed by an owner in his own place of residence
column5: the same reason does not exist for giving an implied admiralty claim upon the bottom
column6: for it is in his power to execute an express transfer or mortgage. There is strong reason to contend that this claim or privilege shall be preferred to every other for the voyage on which the bottomry is founded
column7: except seamen's wages. But it certainly can extend no further. Had the warrant of the admiralty been first served upon the ship
column8: there might be some ground to contend that this court ought not to divest that possession in favour of executions served at a subsequent day
column9: at least to the prejudice of the bond executed by the master. But as the executions in this case were levied before the service of the warrant
column10: and so long after the bonds became due

column1: Some objections have been made to the validity of these executions

for the defendants.

column9: 000 guilders on or before the first day of February
column11: 000 guilders on or before the first day of March

column13: 000 guilders on or before the first day of June

column18: the whole case depends.

column2: on the 13th day of May
column3: at Amsterdam
column4: pay to the bankers of the United States
column5: for the use of the United States
column6: the sum of 170
column7: 000 guilders. The replication admits this payment as pleaded
column8: but denies that it was accepted
column9: received and allowed by the United States in payment and satisfaction of the same sum which was payable on the first of March. The replication proceeds to aver that the said sum of 170
column10: 000 guilders was not paid on the first day of March
column11: nor had the defendants paid the damages of 20 per cent which were stipulated
column12: in case of failure to pay on the day.

column1: The fact upon these pleadings appears to be
column2: that the payment was received by the United States without any *342 stipulation respecting the effect of that receipt
column3: upon their agreement with the defendants. If payment to the bankers of the United States
column4: the persons to whom by agreement the money was to be paid
column5: was not payment to the United States
column6: it would not be a payment to the use of the United States
column7: which the plea avers
column8: and the replication in terms admits. In such case the replication
column9: instead of averring that this sum was not accepted in satisfaction of the same sum payable at an earlier day
column10: would have averred
column11: and ought to have averred
column12: that it was not accepted at all
column13: and was not a payment to the use of the United States
column14: in which case
column15: instead of a special replication
column16: issue might have been tendered on the plea. The court
column17: then
column18: understands the fact as stated in the pleadings to be
column19: that the money was received without any agreement whatever
column20: and the law must determine the effect of such a payment.

column1: The payment made to the bankers in Amsterdam being then an actual payment to the United States
column2: the inquiry is
column3: whether it was such a payment
column4: and is so pleaded
column5: as to bar this action.

column1: It is admitted that the statute of Anne
column2: which allows payment after the day to be pleaded
column3: is in force in Pennsylvania
column4: but it is contended that this bond is not within that statute; or
column5: if it is
column6: that this plea is not good under it.

column1: If this be a bond within the statute of Anne
column2: on which the court gives no opinion
column3: yet by that statute
column4: the payment must be of the whole sum actually due
column5: or the action for the penalty is not barred.

column1: In this case the sum due on the first of March was paid on the 13th of May
column2: without interest or damages.

column1: By the United States it is contended
column2: that damages at the rate of 20 per centum on the sum of 170
column3: 000 guilders were then due; by the defendants it is contended that no interest was due.

column1: *343 The words of the contract to which each party refers
column2: are not precisely the same in the condition of the bond and in the articles of agreement which are referred to by the bond. There is no contradiction between them; but there is a variance in this
column3: that the condition of the bond expresses more fully than the articles the idea of the parties
column4: that in case of failure to perform the contract at Amsterdam
column5: the demand for payment was to be made in Philadelphia. The words of the condition are
column6: "or in case the said sums shall not be paid as aforesaid
column7: then to repay to the United States the value of the said 500
column8: 000 guilders
column9: at the rate of exchange current in Philadelphia at the time demand of payment is made
column10: together with damages at the rate of 20 per cent
column11: in the same manner as if bills of exchange had been drawn for the said sum
column12: and they had been returned protested for non-payment
column13: and lawful interest for any delay of payment that may take place after the demand."

column1: The defendants were merchants residing and carrying on trade in Philadelphia
column2: in which place the contract was made
column3: and by the law of the state
column4: bills of exchange returned unpaid under protest are liable to 20 per cent damages. It is sufficiently obvious
column5: from these circumstances
column6: and from the words of the condition
column7: that the parties contemplated a repayment in Philadelphia in the event of non-payment in Amsterdam.

column1: It is contended by the plaintiffs that
column2: the instant the failure to pay the 170
column3: 000 guilders on the first of March had taken place
column4: a full and complete right to the stipulated damages was vested in the United States
column5: without any further act on their part; and that a payment of the principal sum on the succeeding day would not have relieved the defendants from those damages.

column1: In this opinion the court does not concur with the counsel for the United States.
Contracts are always to be construed with a view to the real intention of the parties. In this contract
column2: the object of the United States was to remit to their bankers in Amsterdam a sum of money
column3: for which they had *344 occasion in Europe. The heavy damages to be incurred by the defendants in the event of their failing to make the stipulated payments in Amsterdam
column4: were considered as a compensation for the disappointments produced by the non-payment of the money at that place in such time as to answer the purposes of the contract. Whether payment at the same place on a subsequent day would answer these purposes
column5: was for the United States to determine. They might accept it
column6: or they might reject it
column7: and claim whatever the law of their contract would give them. In the event of non-payment in Amsterdam at the time stipulated
column8: the defendants are to repay to the United States the value of the guilders they shall have failed to pay in Amsterdam
column9: "at the rate of exchange current in Philadelphia at the time demand of payment is made
column10: together with damages at the rate of 20 per cent." The fair interpretation of this agreement is
column11: that the demand is to be made in Philadelphia
column12: that the money is to be repaid in Philadelphia
column13: and that the damages are upon the money there to be repaid. Had apart of the sum of 170
column14: 000 guilders been paid on the first of March
column15: it will scarcely be contended that damages would have accrued on that part. A repayment of it could not have been demandable in Philadelphia It appears to the court that the acceptance of any part of the sum due in Amsterdam on a subsequent day
column16: is a waiver of the claim to damages in Philadelphia on the sum so accepted
column17: for that sum cannot be demanded in Philadelphia.

column2: to which the majority of the court would strongly incline
column3: from the nature and circumstances of the contract
column4: derives much additional force from the reference to bills of exchange. The repayment of the value of the guilders "at the rate of exchange current in Philadelphia at the time demand of payment is made
column5: together with damages at the rate of 20 per cent
column6: is to be made in the same manner as if bills of exchange had been drawn for the said sum
column7: and they had been returned protested for non-payment."

column1: Why is this reference made to bills of exchange?
*345 The stipulation that damages at the rate of 20 per centum should be incurred on those sums which the defendants might fail to pay at the time and place mentioned in their contract
column2: did not require it
column3: unless the law of bills of exchange was either to explain or to give validity to that stipulation. To a majority of the court it is satisfactory evidence that the parties intended this contract
column4: if not as a complete substitute for bills of exchange
column5: to operate between themselves as if bills had been drawn. The law of Pennsylvania regulating bills of exchange was well understood. If those drawn on any part of Europe are returned back unpaid with a legal protest
column6: the drawers and indorsers are subjected to damages at the rate of 20 per centum. But the right to these damages is not complete until the bill be returned back under protest. Till then they are not demandable. Consequently
column7: payment before the bill returns does away the right to demand them. By receiving payment
column8: the holder waives his right to damages. The express reference to bills which is made in this contract
column9: and the terms in which that reference is made
column10: being considered by the majority of the court as explanatory of the intention of the parties that the right to damages should be put on the same footing as if bills had been drawn
column11: form an additional reason for their opinion that an acceptance in Amsterdam after the day
column12: before a demand in Philadelphia
column13: amounts to a waiver of any right the United States might otherwise
column14: perhaps
column15: have had to demand the stipulated damages.

column1: But whether the sum agreed to be paid as a compensation for a failure to pay at the time and place mentioned in the contract
column2: be considered merely as a penalty
column3: or as stipulated damages
column4: of which the law will coerce the payment
column5: a forfeiture took place on the non-performance of the condition of the bond
column6: and a right to something more than that condition vested immediately in the obligees. If the reservation of damages in the condition of the bond is in law only a double penalty
column7: then interest is the legal compensation for this breach of the covenant contained in the condition of the bond. If it be even of the character given to it by both parties in argument
column8: the amount of damages settled by the parties themselves
column9: the majority of the court *346 is not satisfied
column10: that in waiving those damages the obligee has
column11: without any agreement on the subject
column12: relinquished that right to interest which is attached to all contracts for the payment of money
column13: which is only displaced by the agreement to receive a larger sum in damages
column14: and which a mere tacit implied waiver of those stipulated damages might reinstate. The majority of the court
column15: therefore
column16: is of opinion
column17: that under the circumstances which have taken place
column18: the United States ought to receive
column19: under this contract
column20: interest on the sum of 170
column21: 000 guilders
column22: from the first of March
column23: the day on which that sum ought to have been paid
column24: until the thirteenth of May
column25: the day on which it was actually paid. Judgment
column26: therefore
column27: on the pleadings
column28: must be rendered for the plaintiffs.

column1: By the 26th section of the judicial act
column2: it is directed
column3: that in cases of this description the court shall render "judgment for so much as is due according to equity. And when the sum for which judgment should be rendered is uncertain
column4: the same shall
column5: if either of the parties request it
column6: be assessed by a jury."

column1: In this case it is the opinion of the majority of the court
column2: that judgment ought to be rendered for so much as remains due of the sum of 170
column3: 000 guilders
column4: calculating interest thereon from the first of March in the year 1803
column5: and if either of the parties request it
column6: that a jury be impanelled to ascertain the value of this sum in the money of the United States.

AND

column1: THE CARGO OF THE SHIP FAVOURITE.

column2: United States attorney for the district of Delaware
column3: contended.

column2: contra.
Ch. J. delivered the opinion of the court
column3: as follows:

column1: In these cases two questions are to be decided by the court.
1st. Is the cargo of the Favourite
column2: or any part of it
column3: forfeited to the United States?

column1: 2d. Are Ware and others entitled to any
column2: and if to any
column3: to what salvage?

column1: The first count in the first libel filed on the part of the United States claims the brandies
column2: wines and cordials therein mentioned
column3: in consequence of their being found in the possession of certain persons therein named
column4: unaccompanied *359 with such marks and certificates as are required by law
column5: the duties thereon not having been paid
column6: or secured to be paid.

column1: The second count claims them as forfeited because they were removed
column2: without the consent of the collector
column3: before the quantity and quality of the said wines and spirits
column4: and the duties thereon
column5: were ascertained according to law; the duties thereon not having been paid or secured.

column1: The third count claims them because they were found concealed
column2: the duties not having been paid or secured according to law.

column1: The second libel claims certain other goods
column2: which were parcel of the cargo of the Favourite
column3: as forfeited
column4: by being found unlawfully concealed
column5: the duties thereon not having been paid or secured.

column1: The facts of the case are these: The ship Favourite
column2: belonging to Mr. Peisch
column3: of Philadelphia
column4: was discovered about the last of October adrift in the bay of Delaware
column5: with her masts gone by the board
column6: and without anchors
column7: cables or rudder
column8: and in danger of being carried out to sea. A company was formed to save the vessel and cargo; and with considerable labour
column9: in the course of several days
column10: the cargo was unladen and landed at Lewis
column11: a small town on the bay
column12: not a port of delivery
column13: where it was
column14: with the approbation of the collector
column15: left under the care and in the custody of a revenue officer residing at that place
column16: who was one of the party that had originally taken possession of the vessel
column17: and under whose direction the whole business had been in a great measure conducted. On the 3d of November
column18: while the salvors were unlading the vessel and landing the cargo
column19: an imperfect entry was made by the owners or consignees
column20: after which an award was made between the owners and salvors
column21: by which the salvors were allowed one half the cargo. The owners were dissatisfied with this award
column22: and refused to acquiesce under it. The collector ordered the goods
column23: which had been in the custody of a revenue officer
column24: to be carried to Wilmington for the purpose of *360 ascertaining the amount of duties. The salvors objected to this
column25: and requested that the duties might be ascertained at Lewis
column26: offering at the same time to pay the duties on the moiety of the cargo claimed by them under the award. The collector persisting in his determination to remove the goods to Wilmington
column27: the salvors sued out a writ of replevin from the state court
column28: and by force of that writ took the goods out of the possession of the revenue officer. This act is the foundation of the forfeiture alleged in the libels.

column1: The forfeiture said to be occasioned by the goods being found without the marks and certificates required by law
column2: depends upon the 43d section of the act for collecting duties
column3: and on other sections of the same act
column4: which are explanatory of the 43d section. The particular clause giving the forfeiture is in these words: "And if any casks
column5: chests
column6: vessels or cases
column7: containing distilled spirits
column8: wines
column9: or teas
column10: which by the foregoing provisions ought to be marked and accompanied with certificates
column11: shall be found in possession of any person
column12: unaccompanied with such marks and certificates
column13: it shall be presumptive evidence that the same are liable to forfeiture." The law then authorises a seizure
column14: and subjects such distilled spirits
column15: &c. to forfeiture
column16: unless it be proved at the trial that they were imported according to law
column17: and that the duties were paid or secured.

column1: The objects of this clause are those vessels only which "by the foregoing provisions" ought to be marked and accompanied with certificates. To determine its extent
column2: the "foregoing provisions" must be looked into.

column1: This subject is first taken up in the 37th section of the act. That section directs particular and additional entries to be made of distilled spirits
column2: wines and teas
column3: which provisions are adapted to regular importation
column4: not to those articles when saved from a wreck.

column1: The entry is to be made by the importer or consignee
column2: and specifications are required which can only be given by the owner or consignee
column3: when in possession of the papers relative to the vessel and cargo. If a vessel be *361 wrecked on the coast
column4: the cargo must be lost
column5: or brought on shore without the knowledge of the owner or consignee
column6: so as to put it in his power to make the entry
column7: and the salvors are not only not the persons designated by the law to make
column8: but they will often not possess the information which would enable them to make it.

column1: The act proceeds to require that this entry shall be transmitted to the surveyor of the port where the delivery of the cargo is to commence
column2: to whom also every permit for unlading or landing any part of the cargo must be previously produced
column3: who shall record the same
column4: and indorse thereon the word "inspected
column5:
the time when, and his own name. Goods landed previous to these formalities are to be forfeited.

These regulations obviously respect a regular importation, where all these pre-requisites to landing may be performed; not cases where a landing must take place without them. To suppose them applicable to salvage goods, would be to suppose that the legislature designed to prohibit salvage entirely, or to forfeit the cargoes of all vessels which might be wrecked on the coast.

The 38th section requires that all distilled spirits, wines and teas, shall be landed under the inspection of the surveyor, or other officer acting as inspector of the revenue for the port, and therefore can relate only to cases of regular importation at the port of delivery, where the revenue officer may superintend the landing. He is directed to attend at all reasonable times, not at all places.

The 39th section prescribes the duty of the officer of inspection of the port where the spirits, &c. may be landed. He is to ascertain the duties and mark the casks.

The 40th section directs the surveyor, or chief officer of inspection of the port or district in which the said spirits, wines or teas shall be landed, to give the proprietor, importer or consignee a general certificate; and the 41st section directs him to give a particular certificate *362 for each vessel
column6: which certificate passes with the vessel to the purchaser.

column1: These sections are connected with those which precede them
column2: and relate to regular importations
column3: where the spirits
column4: &c. are landed under a permit at a port of delivery
column5: and there is a proprietor
column6: importer or consignee
column7: or an agent to whom the certificates may be granted; not to spirits
column8: &c. which may
column9: from the nature of things
column10: lawfully get into the possession of individuals without the knowledge of a revenue officer.

column1: The 42d section only directs that blank certificates shall be provided.
These are the sections which precede that which is supposed to give the forfeiture claimed under this count of the libel.
The first part of the 43d section directs the proprietor
column2: importer or consignee
column3: who may receive the said certificates
column4: to deliver them with the vessels to the purchaser; and then comes the clause which subjects to forfeiture all vessels containing spirits
column5: &c. which may be found unmarked and not accompanied by certificates
column6: which by the foregoing provisions ought to be marked and accompanied by certificates.

column2: in the opinion of this court
column3: did not intend to comprehend wrecked goods
column4: or goods found under circumstances like those in the Favourite
column5: where the vessel was deserted by her crew
column6: and where it might be necessary
column7: for the preservation of the goods
column8: to take them to the nearest accessible part of the coast. Either these spirits and wines would have been liable to forfeiture if brought to land under the most pressing circumstances
column9: where inevitable loss must attend any delay
column10: if a revenue officer should not be present to take possession of them
column11: or the single circumstance of their being found unmarked and unaccompanied with certificates
column12: is not in itself sufficient to forfeit them. The opinion of the court that it was not the intention of the legislature to subject goods
column13: under such circumstances
column14: to forfeiture
column15: is not formed exclusively *363 on the extreme severity of such a regulation. It is formed also on what is deemed a fair construction of the language of the several sections of the law
column16: which seems not adapted to cases like the present.

column1: The second count in the libel claims the goods as forfeited
column2: because they were
column3: without the consent of the proper officer
column4: removed from the place where they were deposited
column5: before the amount of duties was ascertained
column6: the duties at that time not being paid or secured.

column2: nor the first
column3: supposes any forfeiture to have been incurred by the landing of the goods
column4: or the unlading of the vessel. The spirits and wines are presumed to have been legally brought on shore
column5: and it is the removal only which gives title to the United States. The court therefore is to inquire
column6: whether these goods were under such circumstances that a removal
column7: such as has taken place in this case
column8: will produce a forfeiture. This depends on the 51st section of the law
column9: in expounding which
column10: it becomes proper to notice the 50th also. This section prohibits the unlading of any vessel
column11: or the landing of any goods
column12: without a permit granted by the proper officers
column13: and subjects the master or other person having the command of such vessel
column14: and all those who shall be concerned in unlading
column15: removing
column16: or storing such goods
column17: to heavy penalties
column18: and the goods themselves to forfeiture.

column1: It was well observed that the application of this section to cases where the goods must perish
column2: if not immediately brought on shore
column3: and to cases in which a permit cannot regularly be granted
column4: would be not only to prohibit
column5: but to punish every attempt to save a cargo about to be lost on the coast. This construction of the law could only be made where the words would admit of no other. But it is unquestionably a correct legal principle
column6: that a forfeiture can only be applied to those cases in which the means that are prescribed for the prevention of a forfeiture may be employed. The means prescribed to save the forfeiture given in the 50th section cannot be employed where a vessel is deserted by her crew
column7: or cannot be brought into port. The permit cannot be obtained
column8: nor can those steps which must precede the attainment *364 of a permit be taken. Upon just legal construction
column9: then
column10: the landing of these goods without a permit did not subject them to the forfeiture of the 50th section. This act is not within the law. The 50th section is calculated for cases in which the general requisites of the law can be complied with
column11: not for salvage goods
column12: in cases where those general requisites cannot be complied with.

column1: The 51st section relates to the removal of goods from the wharf or place on which they may have been landed in conformity with the directions of the 50th section. It presupposes a permit
column2: and that they were landed under the inspection of a revenue officer
column3: in the manner prescribed by the 38th section.

column1: It presupposes a case in which the guaging and marking may be done
column2: and the other means prescribed for the ascertainment of the duties and security of the revenue may be taken
column3: at the place of landing; not a case in which a landing must be made without a permit
column4: often in the absence of a revenue officer
column5: and where the goods could not be permitted
column6: without extreme peril
column7: to remain at the place of landing until these measures should be taken.

column2: that the removal for which the act punishes the owner with a forfeiture of the goods must be made with his consent or connivance
column3: or with that of some person employed or trusted by him. If
column4: by private theft
column5: or open robbery
column6: without any fault on his part
column7: his property should be invaded
column8: while in the custody of the officer of the revenue
column9: the law cannot be understood to punish him with the forfeiture of that property. In the 52d section
column10: therefore
column11: to which the revenue officers seem to have intended to conform
column12: so far as the case would admit
column13: which directs them in the case of an incomplete entry to store the goods at the risk and expense of the owner or consignee
column14: no forfeiture is annexed to their removal
column15: unless the penalties of the 51st section
column16: or of the 43d section
column17: be applied to the 52d.

column1: The court is of opinion that those penalties cannot be so applied in this case
column2: not only because
column3: from the whole *365 tenor of the law
column4: its provisions appear not to be adapted to goods saved from a vessel under the circumstances in which the Favourite was found
column5: but because
column6: also
column7: the law is not understood to forfeit the property of owners or consignees
column8: on account of the misconduct of mere strangers
column9: over whom such owners or consignees could have no controul.

column2: on the part of the United States
column3: that although the property of the owner should not be forfeited
column4: yet that moiety which is claimed by the salvors has justly incurred the penalties of the law. But if the award rendered in this case be not binding
column5: the salvors could have only a general claim for salvage
column6: such as a court might allow; and if it be binding
column7: still they acquired no title to any specific property. Their claim was in the nature of a general lien
column8: and any irregular proceeding on their part would rather furnish motives for diminishing their salvage
column9: if that be not absolutely fixed by the award
column10: than ground of forfeiture. The irregularity
column11: too
column12: if any
column13: which has been committed by them
column14: being merely an attempt to assert
column15: in a course of law
column16: a title they supposed themselves to possess
column17: and with no view to defraud the revenue
column18: this court would not be inclined to put a strained construction on the act of congress
column19: in order to create a forfeiture.

column1: The third count in the first libel
column2: and the second libel
column3: claim a forfeiture on the allegation that the goods were concealed. The fact does not support this allegation. There was no concealment in the case.

column2: it is the unanimous opinion of the court
column3: that no forfeiture has been incurred
column4: and that the libels filed on the part of the United States were properly dismissed.

column1: The next question to be considered is
column2: to what amount of salvage are the salvors entitled? That their claim is good for something
column3: is the opinion of all the judges; but on the amount to be allowed
column4: the same unanimity does not prevail.

column1: *366 For the quantum of salvage to be allowed
column2: no positive rules are fixed. It depends on the merit of the salvors
column3: in estimating which
column4: a variety of considerations have their influence.

column2: the opinion of the majority is
column3: that the sentence of the circuit court ought to be affirmed. This opinion
column4: however
column5: is made up on different grounds. Two of the judges are of opinion that the award was fairly entered into
column6: and although both parties might be mistaken with respect to the obligation created by the law of Delaware
column7: yet there is no reason to suppose any imposition on either part; nor is there any other ground on which the award can be impeached or set aside. Two other judges
column8: who do not think the award obligatory
column9: view it as the opinion of fair and intelligent men
column10: on the spot
column11: of the real merit of the salvors
column12: and connecting it with the testimony in the cause
column13: are in favor of the salvage which has been awarded
column14: and which has been allowed by the sentences of the district and circuit courts. Three judges are of opinion that the award is of no validity
column15: and ought to have no influence. They think the conduct of the salvors
column16: in taking the goods out of the possession of the revenue officer
column17: though by legal process
column18: is improper
column19: and that the salvage allowed is too great.

column2: however
column3: cheerfully
column4: in the opinion of the majority of the court
column5: and express their dissent from that opinion
column6: solely for the purpose of preventing this sentence from having more than its due influence on future cases of salvage.

column1: The sentence of the circuit court is affirmed
column2: without costs.

column1: 8 U.S. 367
2 L. Ed. 649
ERROR to the circuit court for the district of Georgia
column2: in an action of ejectment
column3: brought (on the 15th of October
column5: ) by Irvine's lessee against Shearman
column6: for a tract of land in Camden county
column7: in the state of Georgia.

column1: The defendant below took a bill of exceptions to the refusal of the court
column2: to non suit the plaintiff on the trial
column3: because he had not proved 'an entry within seven years after the title of the grantees accrued
column4: or any entry by either of the heirs or persons claiming under the grantees within seven years after their titles respectively accrued.'

column1: The lessor of the plaintiff had produced in evidence two grants from the province of Georgia
column3: to Alexander Baillie
column4: under whom he claimed title by descent
column5: and whose heir at law he had proved himself to be.

column1: There was no evidence of title
column2: or even of adverse possession on the part of the defendant
column3: before the bringing of the suit
column4: other than the averment of ouster
column5: in the declaration
column6: which was laid on the 10th of September
column7: 1804; nor any evidence of title out of the lessor of the plaintiff.

column1: In support of his motion for a nonsuit
column2: the defendant relied on the act of limitations of Georgia
column3: passed in the year 1767
column4: by which it is enacted 'That all writs of formedon in descender
column5: remainder
column6: and reverter of any lands
column7: &c. or any other writ
column8: suit or action
column9: whatsoever hereafter to be sued or brought by occasion
column10: or means of any title heretofore accrued
column11: happened
column12: or fallen
column13: or which may hereafter descend
column14: happen
column15: or fall
column16: shall be sued or taken within seven years next after the passing of this act
column17: or after the title and cause of action shall or may descend or accrue to the same
column18: and at no time after the said seven years. And that no person or persons that now hath
column19: or have any right or title of entry into any lands
column20: &c. shall at any time hereafter make any entry
column21: but within seven years next after the passing of this act
column22: or after his or their right or title
column23: shall or may descend or accrue to the same

column25: such person so not entering

column2: being against the defendant
column3: he sued out his writ of error.

column1: There being no appearance in this court for the plaintiff in error

column2: for the defendant in error
column3: opened the record
column4: and prayed an affirmance of the judgment;

column1: 1. Because from the facts disclosed
column2: after the descent had been cast nearly thirty years
column3: and no adverse possession at any time proved
column4: the jury had a right to presume and find and actual entry within seven years; if such actual entry was necessary.

column1: In examining the law under which this sale was made

column1: The treaty of peace of 1783 removed all legal impediments to the recovery of debts. By the fourth article

column3: being confiscated
column4: it is not to be inferred that the lien of Greenwood and Higginson on that estate was discharged. The treaty of peace was made while the estate remained unsold. The fifth article of the treaty
column5: after discovering much solicitude on the part of Great Britain for the entire restoration of confiscated estates
column6: concludes with this clause: 'And it is agreed
column7: that all persons who have any interest in confiscated lands
column8: either by debts
column9: marriage settlements
column10: or otherwise
column11: shall meet with no lawful impediment in the prosecution of their just rights.'

column1: This article applies to those cases where an actual confiscation has taken place
column2: and stipulates expressly
column3: that in such cases the interest of all persons having a lien upon such lands shall be preserved. Neither the confiscation
column4: nor any act in consequence of the confiscation
column5: can constitute a legal impediment to the prosecution of their just rights. The preceding part of the article had contemplated sales of the confiscated property
column6: and consequently this clause must have been intended to charge the lands
column7: even in the hands of a purchaser. But respecting its application to this particular case
column8: the court cannot conceive a doubt. The lands
column9: at the time of the treaty
column10: remained unsold
column11: and the government
column12: claiming them as confiscated
column13: stipulates through the proper constituted authorities for their liability to this mortgage. If
column14: then
column15: the act of confiscation
column16: independent of the treaty
column17: would be construed to destroy the claim of the mortgagee
column18: the treaty reinstates the lien in its full force
column19: and the subsequent sale of the property could only pass it with the burden imposed upon it.

column1: 2d. Is this remedy barred by the act of limitations?
Upon an attentive consideration of that act
column2: it appears to be intended for suits at law
column3: claiming the lands themselves
column4: not to suits in equity for the purpose of subjecting the lands to the payment of debts for which they are mortgaged. The words of the law would lead to that opinion
column5: and it is confirmed by the consideration that
column6: in such cases
column7: the possession of the mortgagor
column8: or those claiming under him
column9: is not adverse to
column10: but is compatible with
column11: the rights of the mortgagee. Unless
column12: therefore
column13: this statute has been otherwise construed in Georgia
column14: it would not be considered as applicable to such a case as this. But this point must be decided in favour of the plaintiffs
column15: because there is a saving in the act of the rights of persons beyond sea.

column1: 3d. Is payment in this case to be presumed?
The length of time which elapsed between the day when this bond and mortgage became payable
column2: and that on which the suit was instituted is certainly sufficient to warrant a presumption of payment. But this presumption may be met by circumstances which account for the delay in bringing this suit. In this case
column3: the war
column4: and those events which succeeded the war
column5: have not the same influence as in ordinary cases of British debts
column6: because the debtor was within the reach of his creditor from the date of his banishment in the year 1778
column7: and might have been sued. It does not sufficiently appear in the proceedings where he was
column8: nor what was his situation
column9: to enable the court to judge whether the long delay in bringing this suit is or is not sufficiently accounted for. Neither is it shown satisfactorily that Alexander Wylly has left no personal representative who might show payment of this debt. If there be a personal representative of Alexander Wylly in existence
column10: such person ought to be a party to this suit; if there be no personal representative
column11: some evidence that there is none ought to be adduced. In any event
column12: under all the circumstances of this case
column13: enough does not appear to enable the court to decide whether payment ought to be presumed
column14: or whether the delay in instituting this suit can be accounted for
column15: and the court is therefore of opinion that an issue ought to have been directed by the circuit court
column16: for the purpose of ascertaining the fact of payment. The decree of the circuit court is therefore to be reversed
column17: and the cause remanded to that court
column18: with instructions to direct an issue to determine whether the bond in the bill mentioned has been paid
column19: and with liberty to the plaintiff to amend his bill
column20: and make new parties
column21: if he shall desire it.

column3: but did not state his reasons.

J.<sup>[*]</sup> delivered the opinion of the court
column3: as follows:

column1: This case rests upon the single question
column2: Whether a subject of Great Britain
column3: born before the declaration of independence
column4: can now inherit lands in this country? The general doctrine is admitted
column5: that in the state of Maryland
column6: in which the land lies
column7: an alien cannot take by descent; but it is contended
column8: upon the doctrine laid down in Calvin's case
column9: that the rights of the antenati of Great Britain formed an exception from the general rule. The point decided in the case of Calvin was
column10: that a Scotsman
column11: born after the union
column12: could inherit lands in England. It is evident that this case is not directly in point
column13: for the only objection here to the right of recovery did not exist in Calvin's case
column14: as
column15: whether in England or in Scotland
column16: he was equally bound in allegiance to the king of Great Britain. It would be a contradiction in terms to contend that Dawson or his wife ever owed allegiance to a government which did not exist at their birth. It is upon a supposed analogy
column17: therefore
column18: and the reasoning of the judges in Calvin's case
column19: that the argument for the plaintiffs is founded. In the two cases of Coxe and M`Ilvaine and Lambert and Payne
column20: in this court
column21: this doctrine was very amply discussed
column22: and this case is submitted upon those arguments. The counsel there contended
column23: that the relation of the postnati of Scotland (after the union) to the subjects of Great Britain
column24: was identically the same with the antenati of Great Britain (before our revolution) to the citizens of this country
column25: and that the community of allegiance at the time of birth
column26: and not the existing state of it when the descent is cast
column27: is the principle upon which the right to inherit depends.

column1: The latter proposition presents the weak point of their argument
column2: for the community of allegiance at the time of *323 birth and at the time of descent both existed in Calvin's case. And if the court in their argument expressed opinions which appear to go the length contended for by the counsel
column3: they must be considered as mere obiter opinions
column4: since the decision of the cause did not depend upon them. We have no doubt that the correct doctrine of the English law is
column5: that the right to inherit depends upon the existing state of allegiance at the time of the descent cast. And that the idea that it depends upon community of allegiance at the time of birth
column6: is a consequence that follows from the doctrines that a man can never put off his allegiance
column7: or be deprived of the benefits of it but for a crime. Community of allegiance once existing must
column8: upon these principles
column9: exist ever after. Hence it is that the antenati of America may continue to inherit in Great Britain
column10: because we once owed allegiance to that crown. But the same reason does not extend to the antenati of Great Britain
column11: because they never owed allegiance to our government. This idea will be best elucidated in the following manner: If an action be commenced in England by an antenatus of America for the recovery of land
column12: the plea of alien born could not be maintained
column13: because inconsistent with the fact; nor would a plea of the severance of these states avail the defendant
column14: because the act of his government
column15: independent of any crime of his own
column16: does not deprive the plaintiff of his civil rights
column17: although it may release him from the obligation of allegiance. But if a suit of the same kind be instituted here by an antenatus of Great Britain
column18: the plea of alien born could be maintained
column19: for the plaintiff never owed allegiance to our government. To avoid it he would be put to a special replication
column20: by which he must of necessity acknowledge the truth of the plea
column21: and set forth circumstances which would amount to a recognition of his never having been a party in our social compact. Much of the difficulty in satisfying the mind on this subject vanishes upon a just view of the nature of the right of inheritance. Gentlemen have argued upon it as if it were a natural and perfect right; whereas it has its origin in
column22: and is modified to infinity by the laws of society
column23: in exercise of the right of territorial jurisdiction. To be entitled to inherit in the state of Maryland
column24: a right should be made out under the laws of that state. As the common law
column25: which is the law of Maryland on this subject
column26: *324 deprives an alien generally of the right of inheriting
column27: it is incumbent upon the plaintiff to establish some exception in favour of his case. But I know of no exception
column28: at common law
column29: which gives the right to inherit distinctly from the obligation of allegiance
column30: existing either in fact or in supposition of law.

column3: Livingston and Todd.

for the plaintiffs in error.
