Ch. J. delivered the opinion of the court as follows
column3: viz.

column1: In this case objections have been made to the jurisdiction of the circuit court
column2: and to the proceedings in that court.

column1: The point of jurisdiction made by the plaintiffs in error is considered as free from all doubt. By appearing to the action
column2: the defendants in the court below placed themselves precisely in the situation in which *429 they would have stood
column3: had process been served upon them
column4: and consequently waived all objections to the non-service of process. Were it otherwise
column5: the duty of the circuit court would have been to remand the cause to the state court in which it was instituted
column6: and this court would be bound now to direct that proceeding. As little foundation is there for the exception taken to the manner in which the circuit court was constituted. That court consists of two judges
column7: any one of whom is capable of performing judicial duties. So this court consists of seven judges
column8: any four of whom may act. It has never been supposed that the death of three of the judges would disqualify the remaining four from discharging their official duties until the vacant seats of their departed brethren should be filled. There is nothing in the peculiar phraseology of that part of the judicial act which establishes the circuit courts
column9: that requires a different construction of the words authorising a single judge to hold those courts
column10: from what is usually given in other cases
column11: to clauses authorising a specified number of justices to constitute a court.

column1: The exceptions taken to the proceedings of the circuit court are more serious. These are
2. To the opinions of that court
column2: admitting certain testimony in support of the action.

column1: That the different parts of the declaration are repugnant to each other; and that the declaration is itself insufficient
column2: as the foundation of a judgment.

column1: In deciding on so much of this objection as depends on the laws of Connecticut
column2: this court would certainly be guided by the construction given by that state to its own statute; and
column3: if it was indispensably necessary now to decide that question
column4: the evidence in favour of the construction maintained by the defendants in error would seem to preponderate.

column1: *430 Another objection taken to the declaration is
column2: that it ought to have alleged a disseisin of the plaintiffs below
column3: in order to enable them to maintain their action.

column2: the court can only consider whether the declaration in itself
column3: unconnected with the testimony which was adduced to support it
column4: is so radically defective
column5: that a judgment cannot be rendered on it. This leads to the inquiry
column6: whether the covenant of the vendors can be broken
column7: as stated in the declaration
column8: although no eviction has taken place; and the court is of opinion that it may be so broken. 9 Co. 60.

column2: that the vendor is seised in fee of the premises which he sells and conveys. Suppose the fact to be that he had no title nor pretence of title to those premises; that he had conveyed lands for which he had never received a patent or a title of any kind. Could it be said that his covenant that he was seised in fee remained unbroken until the real proprietor should think proper to eject the vendee? This question
column3: in the opinion of the court
column4: must be answered in the negative. The testimony
column5: which would be sufficient to establish the breach assigned
column6: may be a subject for serious consideration
column7: but on the sufficiency of the breach as assigned to support a judgment
column8: there is no doubt.

column1: The exceptions to the testimony admitted in the circuit court consists of two parts.
1st. To the admission of certain copies of surveys made for Wilson Carey Nicholas
column2: connected with the testimony of Erastus Granger
column3: describing the face of the country on which the surveys purported to be made.

column1: 2d. To the admission of parol testimony to prove prior titles to the lands conveyed in the deed on which this suit was instituted.
1. The surveys of Wilson Carey Nicholas
column2: and the explanatory testimony of Granger
column3: were introduced for the purpose of showing that the patent for the lands sold by Pollard and Pickett was void
column4: because it issued on a *431 plat representing a survey which
column5: in point of fact
column6: could not have been made.

column2: it becomes proper to inquire what was the real issue between the parties.

column1: The plaintiffs below averred in their declaration that the defendants were not seised and possessed of any estate whatever in the land and premises
column2: nor in any part thereof
column3: nor had they or either of them good right and lawful authority to sell and convey the same. The defendants
column4: in their plea
column5: do not set forth their title
column6: but say generally that they were seised of the land sold and conveyed by them
column7: and had good right to sell and convey the same
column8: as is expressed by their deed. On this plea an issue is tendered
column9: which is joined by the plaintiffs.

column1: To prove that the survey on which the patent granting the lands to the defendants was issued could not have been made
column2: the plaintiffs produced two other surveys made by the same person for Wilson Carey Nicholas
column3: which were said to be completed only two days succeeding the completion of the survey of the defendants
column4: which three several surveys could not possibly have been made in the time intervening between the entries in the surveyor's office and the day on which they are alleged to have been completed
column5: whence the jury might conclude that the survey of Pollard and Pickett was not made.

column2: and his survey was returned upon oath. This is an attempt to invalidate the evidence derived from his official return
column3: by a particular fact which has no relation to the cause before the court
column4: and with which the parties to this controversy have no connection. Had it even appeared that the copies offered in evidence were authenticated
column5: they would
column6: on this account
column7: have been inadmissible.

column1: This whole testimony is inadmissible on other ground. Were it even true that this patent is voidable
column2: if the surveyor had not run round all the lines of the land
column3: a *432 point not yet established
column4: it cannot be deemed absolutely void; it cannot be deemed a mere nullity. While it remains in force it is a valid title
column5: and vests the fee-simple estate in the patentee. In this action
column6: and on the trial of this issue
column7: the question whether the patent be voidable by Virginia or not
column8: is not properly examinable. Testimony
column9: therefore
column10: tending to establish that point
column11: is irrelevant and inadmissible.

column1: 2. But had the court enteritaned any doubt on this point
column2: the second part of the exception would be clearly decisive with regard to this judgment.

column1: Parol testimony is admitted to show prior claims to the land in controversy. The defendants in error attempt to defend the admission of this testimony
column2: by supposing it auxiliary to other testimony which had previously established the validity of those claims
column3: and that this witness was only adduced to show that those claims covered this land. Had the fact supported the argument
column4: a private ex parte survey would have been a very improper mode of establishing it; but the language of the exception excludes that construction of the opinion which the counsel for the defendants in error would put upon it. The proof offered and admitted is
column5: not that those particular titles which were exhibited and proved to the court covered the land conveyed by Pollard and Pickett
column6: but "that there were prior claims upon it to the amount of upwards of ninety thousand acres." The prior claims rest upon the oath of the witness. If those claims were valid
column7: their validity was established by his testimony
column8: which cannot be tolerated on any legal principle; if they were mere claims
column9: not good titles
column10: they ought not to have been stated to the jury. They were irrelevant to the point in issue.

column2: the court is unanimously of opinion
column3: that the circuit court erred in permitting the copies of surveys made for Wilson Carey Nicholas
column4: and the testimony of Erastus Granger
column5: to go to the jury for the purposes mentioned in the bill of exceptions
column6: and *433 that the judgment of the circuit court must
column7: on that account
column8: be reversed
column9: and the cause remanded for a new trial.[*]

column1: [*] After the opinion of the court was delivered
column2: Lee prayed that the cause might be remanded
column3: with leave for the defendants below to amend their pleadings.

column2: that the court below had the power to grant leave to amend
column3: and this court could not doubt but it would do what was right
column4: in that respect.

column2: |[<div id="opinion-content">

column1: The action below was instituted on a policy of insurance.

column2: it was contended that the policy was forfeited by committing a breach of blockade. It is not
column3: and cannot be made a question
column4: that this is one of those acts which will exonerate the underwriters from their liability. The only point below was relative to the evidence upon which the commission of *435 the act may be substantiated. A sentence of a British prize court in Barbadoes was given in evidence
column5: by which it appeared that the vessel was condemned for attempting to commit a breach of blockade. It is the English doctrine
column6: and the correct doctrine on the law of nations
column7: that an attempt to commit a breach of blockade is a violation of belligerent rights
column8: and authorises capture. This doctrine is not denied
column9: but the plaintiff contends that he did not commit such an attempt
column10: and the court below permitted evidence to go to the jury to disprove the fact on which the condemnation professes to proceed.

column2: I am of opinion that the court below erred.

column1: I do not think it necessary to go through the mass of learning on this subject
column2: which has so often been brought to the notice of this court
column3: and particularly in the case of Fitzsimmons
column4: argued at this term. Nearly the whole of it will be found very well summed up in the 18th chapter of Mr. Park's Treatise. The doctrine appears to me to rest upon three very obvious considerations: the propriety of leaving the cognizance of prize questions exclusively to courts of prize jurisdiction  the very great inconvenience amounting nearly to an impossibility of fully investigating such cases in a court of common law  and the impropriety of revising the decisions of the maritime courts of other nations
column5: whose jurisdiction is co-ordinate throughout the world.

column1: It is sometimes contended that this doctrine is novel
column2: and that it takes its origin in an incorrect extension of the principle in Hughes v. Cornelius. I am induced to believe that it is coeval with the species of contract to which it is applied. Policies of insurance are known to have been brought into England from a country that acknowledged the civil law. This must have been the law of policies at the time when they were considered as contracts proper for the admiralty jurisdiction
column3: and were submitted to the court of policies established in the reign of Elizabeth. It is probable that
column4: at the time when the common law assumed to itself exclusive jurisdiction of the contract of insurance
column5: the rule was *436 too much blended with the law of policies to have been dispensed with
column6: had it even been inconsistent with common law principles. But
column7: in fact
column8: the common law had sufficient precedent for this rule
column9: in its own received principles relative to sentences of the civil law courts of England. It may be true that there are no cases upon this subject prior to that of Hughes v. Cornelius
column10: but this does not disprove the existence of the doctrine. There can be little necessity for reporting decisions upon questions that cannot be controverted. Since the case of Hughes v. Cornelius
column11: the doctrine has frequently been brought to the notice of the courts of Great Britain in insurance cases
column12: but always with a view to contest its applicability to particular cases
column13: or to restrict the general doctrine by exceptions
column14: but the existence of the rule
column15: or its applicability to actions on policies
column16: is no where controverted.

column1: I am of opinion that the sentence of condemnation was conclusive evidence of the commission of the offence for which the vessel was condemned
column2: and as that offence was one which vitiated the policy
column3: the defendants ought to have had a verdict.

column2: J. The single question in this case is
column3: whether the sentence of the admiralty court at Barbadoes
column4: condemning the brig Fame and her cargo as prize
column5: for an attempt to break the blockade of Martinique
column6: is conclusive evidence against the insured
column7: to falsify his warranty of neutrality
column8: notwithstanding the fact stated in the sentence as the ground of condemnation is negatived by the jury?

column1: This question has long been at rest in England. The established law upon this subject in the courts of that country is
column2: that the sentence of a foreign court of competent jurisdiction condemning the property upon the ground that it was not neutral
column3: is so entirely conclusive of the fact so decided
column4: that it can never be controverted
column5: directly or collaterally
column6: in any other court having concurrent jurisdiction.

column1: This doctrine seems to result from the application of a legal principle which prevails in respect to domestic *437 judgments
column2: to the judgments and sentences of foreign courts.

column1: It is a well established rule in England
column2: that the judgment
column3: sentence
column4: or decree of a court of exclusive jurisdiction directly upon the point
column5: may be given in evidence as conclusive between the same parties
column6: upon the same matter coming incidentally in question in another court for a different purpose. It is not only conclusive of the right which it establishes
column7: but of the fact which it directly decides.

column2: when applied to the sentences of courts of admiralty
column3: whether foreign or domestic
column4: produces the doctrine which I am now considering
column5: upon the ground that all the world are parties in an admiralty cause. The proceedings are in rem
column6: but any person having an interest in the property may interpose a claim
column7: or may prosecute an appeal from the sentence. The insured is emphatically a party
column8: and in every instance has an opportunity to controvert the alleged grounds of condemnation
column9: by proving
column10: if he can
column11: the neutrality of the property. The master is his immediate agent
column12: and he is also bound to act for the benefit of all concerned
column13: so that
column14: in this respect
column15: he also represents the insurer. That irregularities have sometimes taken place
column16: to the exclusion of a fair hearing of the parties
column17: is not to be denied. But this furnishes no good reason against the adoption of a general rule. A spirit of comity has induced the courts of England to presume that foreign tribunals
column18: whether of prize or municipal jurisdiction
column19: will act fairly
column20: and will decide according to the laws which ought to govern them; and public convenience seems to require that a question
column21: which has once been fairly decided
column22: should not be again litigated between the same parties
column23: unless in a court of appellate jurisdiction.

column1: The irregular and unjust decisions of the French courts of admiralty of late years
column2: have induced even English judges to doubt of the wisdom of the above doctrine in relation to foreign sentences
column3: but which they have acknowledged to be too well established for English tribunals to shake; and the justice with which the same *438 charge is made by all neutral nations against the English as well as against the French courts of admiralty
column4: during the same period
column5: has led many American jurists to question the validity of the doctrine in the courts of our own country. It is said to be a novel doctrine
column6: lately sprung up
column7: and acted upon as a rule of decision in the English courts
column8: since the period when English decisions have lost the weight of authority in the courts of the United States. It is this position which I shall now examine
column9: acknowledging that I do not hold myself bound by such decisions made since the revolution
column10: although
column11: as evidence of what the law was prior to that period
column12: I read and respect them.

column1: The authority of the case of Hughes v. Cornelius
column2: the earliest we meet with as to the conclusiveness of a foreign sentence
column3: is admitted; but its application to a question arising under a warranty of neutrality between the insurer and insured
column4: is denied. It is true that
column5: in that case
column6: the only point expressly decided was
column7: that the sentence was conclusive as to the change of property effected by the condemnation. But it is obvious that the point decided in that case depended
column8: not upon some new principle peculiar to the sentences of foreign courts
column9: but upon the application of a general rule of law to such sentences.

column2: as far as it goes
column3: places a foreign sentence upon the same foundation as the sentence or decree of an English court acting upon the same subject; and we have seen that
column4: by the general rule of law
column5: the latter
column6: if conclusive at all
column7: is so as to the fact directly decided
column8: as well as to the change of property produced by the establishment of the fact. Hence it would seem to follow
column9: that if the sentence of a foreign court of admiralty be conclusive as to the property
column10: it is equally conclusive of the matter or fact directly decided. What is the matter decided in the case under consideration?  That the vessel was seized whilst attempting to break a blockade
column11: in consequence of which she lost her neutral character; and the change of property produced by the sentence of condemnation is a consequence of the matter decided
column12: that she was
column13: in effect
column14: enemy-property. Can the parties to that sentence be bound by so much of *439 it as works a loss of the property
column15: because it was declared to be enemy-property
column16: and yet be left free to litigate anew in some other form
column17: the very point decided from which this consequence flowed? Or upon what just principle
column18: let me ask
column19: shall a party to a suit
column20: who has once been heard
column21: and whose rights have been decided by a competent tribunal
column22: be permitted in another court of concurrent jurisdiction
column23: and
column24: in a different form of action
column25: to litigate the same question
column26: and to take another chance for obtaining a different result? I confess I am strongly inclined to think that the case of Hughes v. Cornelius laid a strong foundation for the doctrine which was built upon it
column27: and which for many years past has been established law in England. This opinion is given with the more confidence
column28: when I find it sanctioned by the positive declarations of distinguished law characters  men who are
column29: of all others
column30: the best able to testify respecting the course of decisions upon the doctrine I am examining
column31: and the source from which it sprung.

column1: In the case of Lothian v. Henderson
column2: 3 Bos. & Pull. 499. Chambre
column3: J. speaking upon this point
column4: says that the sentence of the French court was in that case conclusive against the claim of the assured
column5: "agreeable to all the decisions upon the subject
column6: beginning with the case of Hughes v. Cornelius
column7: (confirmed as that was by the opinion of Lord Holt in two subsequent cases
column8: ) and pursuing them down to the present period. It is true
column9: he observes, that in Hughes v. Cornelius
column10: the question upon the foreign sentence arose in an action of trover
column11: and not in an action on a policy of assurance
column12: where the non-compliance with a warranty of neutrality is in dispute. But from that period to the present
column13: the doctrine there laid down respecting foreign sentences has been considered equally applicable to questions of warranty in actions on policies
column14: as to questions of property in actions of trover." Le Blanc
column15: J. says
column16: "that these sentences are admissible and conclusive evidence of the fact they decide
column17: it seems not safe now to question. From the time of Car. II. to this day
column18: they have been received as such
column19: without being questioned. In the discussion of the nature of such evidence before this *440 house in 1776
column20: it seems not to have been controverted
column21: and the cases
column22: I may say
column23: are numberless
column24: and the property immense which have been determined on the conclusiveness of such evidence
column25: in many of which cases
column26: the forms in which they came before the courts in Westminster-Hall were such as to have enabled the parties
column27: if any doubt had been entertained
column28: to have brought the question before a higher tribunal." Lawrence
column29: J. also speaking of the legal effect of a foreign sentence upon this point
column30: says
column31: "as to which
column32: after the continued practice which has taken place from the earliest period
column33: in which
column34: in actions on policies of insurance
column35: questions have arisen on warranties
column36: to admit such sentences in evidence
column37: not only as conclusive in rem
column38: but also as conclusive of the several matters they purport to decide directly
column39: I apprehend it is now too late to examine the practice of admitting them to the extent to which they have been received
column40: supposing that practice might
column41: upon the argument
column42: have appeared to have been doubtful at first." Rooke
column43: J. Lord Eldon
column44: and Lord Alvanley
column45: all concur in giving the same testimony
column46: that the doctrine under consideration had been established for a long period of years
column47: by a long series of adjudications in the courts of Westminster-Hall.

column1: I cite this case for no other purpose but to prove by the most respectable testimony
column2: that the case of Hughes v. Cornelius
column3: decided in the reign of Car. II. had
column4: by a uniform course of decisions from that time
column5: been considered as warranting the rule now so firmly established in England. And when the inquiry is
column6: whether the application of the principle laid down in that case to questions arising on warranties in actions on policies
column7: be of ancient or modern date
column8: I think I may safely rely upon the declarations of the English judges
column9: when they concur in the evidence they give respecting the fact. It is true that no case was cited at the bar recognizing the application of the rule to questions between the insurer and insured
column10: prior to the revolution
column11: except that of Fernandez v. Da Costa
column12: which I admit was a Nisi Prius decision. But were I convinced that the long series of decisions upon this point
column13: from the time of Hughes v. Cornelius
column14: spoken of by the judges in the case of Lothian v. Henderson
column15: had been made at Nisi Prius
column16: it *441 would not
column17: in my mind
column18: weaken the authority of the doctrine. It would prove the sense of all the judges of England
column19: as well as of the bar

column9: strongly marks the distinguishing point between them. In its ordinary jurisdiction
column10: the admiralty takes cognizance of mere questions of meum and tuum arising between individuals; its extraordinary or prize jurisdiction is vested in it for the purpose of revising the acts of the sovereign himself performed through the agency of his officers or subjects. A seizure on the high seas by an unauthorised individual
column11: is a mere trespass
column12: and produces no change of right
column13: but such a seizure made by sovereign authority
column14: vests the thing seized in the sovereign; for the fact of possession must have all the beneficial effects of the right of possession
column15: as the justice or propriety of it cannot be inquired into by the courts of other nations. But as this principle might leave the unoffending individual a prey to the rapacity of cruisers

column1: The ocean is the common jurisdiction of all sovereign powers; from which it does not result that their powers upon the ocean exist in a state of suspension or equipoise

column3: provided it

column10: and every nation is the legal avenger of its own wrongs. Within their jurisdictional limits the rights of sovereignty are exclusive; upon the ocean they are concurrent. Whatever the great principle of self defence in its reasonable and necessary exercise will sanction in an individual in a state of nature
column11: nations may lawfully perform upon the ocean. This principle
column12: as well as most others

column1: But the capture of The Sarah may fairly be considered as an exercise of belligerent right
column2: and strictly analogous to seizure for breach of blockade. The right of one nation to exclude all others from trading with her territories
column3: exists equally in war and in peace. Had the exclusion in this case been merely calculated for the interests of trade
column4: it may have been considered as purely municipal. But there existed a war between the parent state and her colony. It was not only a fact of the most universal notoriety
column5: but officially notified in the gazettes of the United States
column6: by the proclamation of the French resident M. Pichon
column7: who at the same time publishes the prohibition to trade with the revolters
column8: with a declaration that seizure and confiscation should be the consequence of disobedience to this prohibition. Here then was notice of the existence of war
column9: and an assertion *289 of the rights consequent upon it. The object of the measure was not the promotion of any particular branch of agriculture
column10: manufacture
column11: or commerce
column12: but solely the reduction of an enemy. It was therefore not merely municipal
column13: but belligerent in its nature and object. If France had a right to subdue the revolted colony
column14: she had an undoubted right to preclude all nations from supplying them with the means of protracting the war. To confine her to her own jurisdictional limits
column15: in the exercise of those acts of force which were necessary to carry into effect her right of excluding neutrals
column16: would be a mere mockery
column17: when by the very state of things she was herself shut out from those limits. Seizure on the high seas for a breach of the right of blockade
column18: during the whole return voyage
column19: is universally acquiesced in as a reasonable exercise of sovereign power. The principle of blockade has indeed in modern times been pushed to such an extravagant extent as to become a very justifiable cause of war
column20: but still it is admitted to be consistent with the law of nations
column21: when confined within the limits of reason and necessity. The right to subdue an enemy
column22: carries with it the right to make use of the necessary means for that purpose
column23: and the individual who does an act inconsistent with the rights of a belligerent
column24: exposes himself to the liability to be treated as an enemy. The belligerent nation can exercise the same acts of violence against him that she can against an individual of her enemy. Nor can his sovereign protect an individual who has committed an aggression upon belligerent rights without becoming a party to the contest.

column1: The argument drawn from the decree of Ferrand

column15: and yet the character of the seizure would be in no wise changed. If the object of the seizure is to promote the reduction of an enemy
column16: it is an exercise of the rights of war.

column1: Admitting for the present that the sentence of a foreign court of admiralty is conclusive
column2: with respect to what it professes to decide
column3: does this sentence falsify the warranty contained in this policy
column4: that the brig John is American property?

column1: The sentence declares "the said brig to have been cleared out for Cadiz
column2: a port actually blockaded by the arms of our sovereign lord the king
column3: and that the master of said brig persisted in his intention of entering that port
column4: after warning from the blockading force not to do so
column5: in a direct breach and violation of the blockade thereby notified."

column2: then
column3: does not deny the brig to have been American property. But it is contended by the counsel for the underwriters
column4: that a ship warranted to be American is impliedly warranted to conduct herself during the voyage as an American
column5: and that an attempt to enter a blockaded port
column6: knowing it to be blockaded
column7: forfeits that character.

column2: then
column3: to inquire
column4: whether the sentence proves the brig John to have violated the laws of blockade; that is
column5: whether the cause of condemnation is alleged in such terms as to show that the vessel had forfeited her neutral character
column6: or in such terms as to show its insufficiency to support the sentence.

column1: The fact of clearing out for a blockaded port
column2: is in itself innocent
column3: unless it be accompanied with knowledge of the blockade. The clearance
column4: therefore
column5: is not considered as the offence; the persisting in the intention to enter that port
column6: after warning by the blockading force
column7: is the ground of the sentence.

column1: Is this intention (evidenced by no fact whatever) a breach of blockade? This question is to be decided by *199 a reference to the law of nations
column2: and to the treaty between the United States and Great Britain.
b. 3. s. 177. says
column3: "All commerce is entirely prohibited with a besieged town. If I lay siege to a place
column4: or only from the blockade
column5: I have a right to hinder any one from entering
column6: and to treat as an enemy whoever attempts to enter the place
column7: or carry any thing to the besieged
column8: without my leave."

column1: The right to treat the vessel as an enemy is declared
column2: by Vattel
column3: to be founded on the attempt to enter
column4: and certainly this attempt must be made by a person knowing the fact.

column1: But this subject has been precisely regulated by the treaty between the United States and Great Britain
column2: which was in force when this condemnation took place. That treaty contains the following clause:

column1: "And whereas it frequently happens that vessels sail for a port or place belonging to an enemy
column2: without knowing that the same is either besieged
column3: blockaded or invested; it is agreed that every vessel so circumstanced may be turned away from such port or place
column4: but she shall not be detained
column5: nor her cargo
column6: if not contraband
column7: be confiscated
column8: unless after notice she shall again attempt to enter; but she shall be permitted to go to any other port or place she may think proper."

column1: This treaty is conceived to be a correct exposition of the law of nations; certainly it is admitted by the parties to it
column2: as between themselves
column3: to be a correct exposition of that law
column4: or to constitute a rule in the place of it.

column1: Neither the law of nations nor the treaty admits of the condemnation of the neutral vessel for the intention to enter a blockaded port
column2: unconnected with any fact. Sailing for a blockaded port
column3: knowing it to be blockaded
column4: has been in some English cases construed into an attempt to enter that port
column5: and has therefore been adjudged a breach of the blockade from the departure of the vessel. *200 Without giving any opinion on that point
column6: it may be observed
column7: that in such cases the fact of sailing is coupled with the intention
column8: and the sentence of condemnation is founded on an actual breach of blockade. The cause assigned for condemnation would be a justifiable cause
column9: and it would be for the foreign court alone to determine whether the testimony supported the allegation that the blockade was broken. Had this sentence averred that the brig John had broken the blockade
column10: or had attempted to enter the port of Cadiz after warning from the blockading force
column11: the cause of condemnation would have been justifiable
column12: and without controverting the conclusiveness of the sentence
column13: the assured could not have entered into any inquiry respecting the conduct of the vessel. But this is not the language of the sentence. An attempt to enter the port of Cadiz is not alleged
column14: but persisting in the intention
column15: after being warned not to enter it
column16: is alleged as the cause of condemnation. This is not a good cause under the treaty. It is impossible to read that instrument without perceiving a clear intention in the parties to it
column17: that after notice of the blockade
column18: an attempt to enter the port must be made
column19: in order to subject the vessel to confiscation. By the language of the treaty it would appear that a second attempt
column20: after receiving notice
column21: must be made
column22: in order to constitute the offence which will justify a confiscation. "It is agreed
column23: says that instrument, that every vessel so circumstanced" (that is
column24: every vessel sailing for a blockaded port
column25: without knowledge of the blockade) "may be turned away from such port or place
column26: but she shall not be detained
column27: nor her cargo
column28: if not contraband
column29: be confiscated
column30: unless after notice she shall again attempt to enter."

column1: These words strongly import a stipulation that there shall be a free agency on the part of the commander of the vessel
column2: after receiving notice of the blockade
column3: and that there shall be no detention nor condemnation
column4: unless
column5: in the exercise of that free agency
column6: a second attempt to enter the invested place shall be made.

column1: It cannot be necessary to state that testimony which would amount to evidence of such second attempt. Lingering about the place
column2: as if watching for an opportunity *201 to sail into it
column3: or the single circumstance of not making immediately for some other port
column4: or possibly obstinate and determined declarations of a resolution to break the blockade
column5: might be evidence of an attempt
column6: after warning
column7: to enter the blockaded port. But whether these circumstances
column8: or others
column9: may or may not amount to evidence of the offence
column10: the offence itself is attempting again to enter
column11: and "unless
column12: after notice
column13: she shall again attempt to enter
column14: the two nations expressly stipulate that she shall not be detained
column15: nor her cargo
column16: if not contraband
column17: be confiscated." It would seem as if
column18: aware of the excesses which might be justified
column19: by converting intention into offence
column20: the American negotiator had required the union of fact with intention
column21: to constitute the breach of a blockade.

column2: then
column3: as described in this sentence
column4: is one which
column5: by express compact between the United States and Great Britain
column6: is an insufficient cause
column7: unless the intention was manifested in such manner as
column8: in fair construction
column9: to be equivalent to an attempt to enter Cadiz
column10: after knowledge of the blockade. This not being proved by the sentence itself
column11: the parties are let in to other evidence.

column2: then
column3: the sentence may be
column4: of the particular facts which it alleges
column5: those facts not amounting
column6: in themselves
column7: to a justifiable cause of condemnation
column8: the court must look into the special verdict
column9: which explains what is uncertain in the sentence. The special verdict shows that the vessel was seized on her approaching the port of Cadiz
column10: without previous knowledge of the blockade; that she never was turned away
column11: and "permitted to go to any other port or place;" that she was "detained" for several days
column12: and then sent in for adjudication
column13: without being ever put into the possession of her captain and crew
column14: so as to enable her either "again to attempt to enter" the port of Cadiz
column15: or to sail for some other port; that while thus detained
column16: the commander of the blockading squadron drew the captain of the John into a conversation which must be termed insidious
column17: since its object was to trepan him into expressions which might be construed into evidence of an intention to sail for Cadiz
column18: should he be liberated; *202 that availing himself of some equivocal
column19: unguarded
column20: and perhaps indiscreet answers on the part of the captain
column21: the vessel was sent in for adjudication; and on those expressions was condemned.

column1: This court is of opinion that these facts do not amount to an attempt again to enter the port of Cadiz
column2: and therefore do not amount
column3: under the treaty between the United States and Great Britain
column4: to a breach of the blockade of Cadiz. The sentence of the court of vice-admiralty in Gibraltar
column5: therefore
column6: is not considered as falsifying the warranty that the brig John was American property
column7: or as disabling the assured from recovering against the underwriters in this action
column8: and the testimony in the case shows that the blockade was not broken.

column1: The judgment of the circuit court is to be reversed
column2: with costs
column3: and it is to be certified to that court
column4: that judgment is to be entered on the special verdict for the plaintiff.

column1: *206 The question submitted to the consideration of the court is this: Is the assured entitled to recover for a partial or for a total loss?
In support of the claim for a total loss
column2: two points have been made:

column1: 1st. That the state of information at the time of the abandonment
column2: not the state of the fact
column3: must decide the right of the assured to abandon.

column2: then
column3: it is contended

column1: 2d. That the right to abandon is coextensive with the detention
column2: which continued until restitution was made in fact
column3: and that restitution in fact
column4: though made on the same day
column5: was posterior in point of time to the abandonment.

column1: 1. Does the right to abandon depend on the fact
column2: or on the information of the parties?

column1: The right to abandon is founded on an actual or legal total loss. It appears to the court to consist with the nature of the contract
column2: which is truly stated to be a contract of indemnity
column3: that the real state of loss at the time the abandonment is made
column4: is the proper and safe criterion of the rights of the parties. Might they depend absolutely on the state of information
column5: a seizure which scarcely interrupted the voyage might be
column6: and frequently would be converted into a total loss
column7: and the contests respecting the real state of information might be endless. Intelligence of capture and of restitution might be received at the same time
column8: and the insured might suppress the one and act upon the other.

column1: This point came under the consideration of the court in the case of Rhinelander v. The Insurance Company of Pennsylvania
column2: in which case it was said
column3: that "where a belligerent has taken full possession of a vessel as prize
column4: and continues that possession to the time of the abandonment
column5: there exists
column6: in point of law
column7: a total loss." The court
column8: in delivering this opinion
column9: understood itself to require
column10: that the continuance of the possession *207 up to the time of the abandonment
column11: or a technical total loss incurred
column12: notwithstanding the restoration
column13: was necessary to justify a recovery as for a total loss.

column2: the court proceeded to inquire whether the technical total loss on which the right to abandon depended
column3: was terminated by the decree of restitution
column4: or continued until that decree was carried into execution
column5: and restitution was made in fact.

column1: The real object of the policy is not to effect a change in property
column2: but to indemnify the insured. Whenever
column3: therefore
column4: only a partial loss is sustained by one of the perils insured against
column5: the original owner of the property retains it
column6: prosecutes his voyage
column7: and recovers for his partial loss.

column1: But the voyage may be really broken up
column2: without the destruction of the vessel and cargo. A detention by a foreign prince
column3: either by embargo or capture
column4: may be of such long duration as to defeat the voyage. This is a peril insured against
column5: and of its continuance no certain estimate can be made. In the case of capture it is
column6: for the time
column7: a total loss
column8: and no person can confidently say that the loss will not finally be total. So of an embargo. Its duration cannot be measured
column9: and it may destroy the object of the voyage. These detentions
column10: therefore
column11: are
column12: for the time
column13: total losses
column14: and they furnish reasonable ground for the apprehension that their continuance may be of such duration as to break up the voyage
column15: or ruin the assured
column16: by keeping his property out of his possession. Such a case
column17: therefore
column18: upon the true principles of the contract
column19: has been considered as justifying an abandonment
column20: and a recovery for a total loss.

column1: But when a final decree of restitution
column2: from which it is admitted that no appeal lies
column3: has been awarded
column4: the peril is over. On no reasonable calculation can it be supposed that such a delay of restitution will ensue
column5: as from that time to break up the voyage. There is no reason to presume a subsequent detention on the part of *208 the foreign prince. There is no motive for such detention. The master of the captured vessel may perhaps not be ready to receive possession
column6: and the delay may proceed from him. At any rate
column7: without some evidence that the peril was not actually determined
column8: the court cannot consider it as continuing after the sentence was pronounced. A technical total loss originates in the danger of a real total loss. The court cannot suppose such a danger to have existed after a final sentence of acquittal
column9: unless some order of court relative to a reconsideration could be shown
column10: or it should appear that some other delays were interposed by the court which had pronounced the sentence
column11: or by the sovereign of the captor.

column1: Had the facts on which this question depends been known at New-York and Philadelphia as they occurred
column2: could it have been said that there existed a technical total loss? After a decree of restitution
column3: could it be said that while means were taking to carry that decree into execution
column4: while the mandate for restitution was passing from the court to the vessel
column5: the assured had a right to elect to consider his vessel as lost
column6: and to abandon to the underwriters? To this court
column7: it seems that the right to make such an election at such a time
column8: would be inconsistent with the spirit of the contract
column9: and that the technical total loss was terminated by the decree of restitution
column10: unless something subsequent to that decree could be shown to prove the continuance of the danger
column11: or of an adversary detention.

column1: Nothing in this opinion is intended to extend to the case where a cargo may be lost
column2: without the loss of the vessel.

column1: The court deems it unnecessary to declare an opinion upon a point which was much debated in this cause
column2: whether a real British subject born before the 4th of July
column3: 1776; who never from the time of his birth
column4: resided within any of the American colonies or states
column5: can
column6: upon the principles of the common law
column7: take lands by descent in the United States; because Daniel Coxe
column8: under whom the lessor of the plaintiff claims
column9: was born in the province of New-Jersey
column10: long before the declaration of independence
column11: and resided there until some time in the year 1777
column12: when he joined the British forces.

column1: Neither does this case produce the necessity of discriminating very nicely the precise point of time
column2: when *212 Daniel Coxe lost his right of election to abandon the American cause
column3: and to adhere to his allegiance to the king of Great Britain; because he remained in the state of New-Jersey; not only after she had declared herself a sovereign state
column4: but after she had passed laws by which she pronounced him to be a member of
column5: and in allegiance to the new government. The court entertains no doubt that after the 4th of October
column7: he became a member of the new society
column8: entitled to the protection of its government
column9: and bound to that government by the ties of allegiance.

column1: This opinion is predicated upon a principle which is believed to be undeniable
column2: that the several states which composed this union
column3: so far at least as regarded their municipal regulations became entitled
column4: from the time when they declared themselves independent
column5: to all the rights and powers of sovereign states
column6: and that they did not derive them from concessions made by the British king. The treaty of peace contains a recognition of their independence
column7: not a grant of it. From hence it results
column8: that the laws of the several state governments were the laws of sovereign states
column9: and as such were obligatory upon the people of such state
column10: from the time they were enacted. We do not mean to intimate an opinion that even the law of a state
column11: whose form of government had been organized prior to the 4th of July
column13: and which passed prior to that period
column14: would not have been obligatory. The present case renders it unnecessary to be more precise in stating the principle; for although the constitution of New-Jersey was formed previous to the general declaration of independence
column15: the laws passed upon the subject now under consideration were posterior to it.

column1: Having thus ascertained the situation of Daniel Coxe
column2: on the 4th of October
column4: let us see whether it was in any respect changed by his subsequent conduct
column5: in relation to the new government. Without expressing an opinion upon the right of expatriation as founded on the common law
column6: or upon the application of that principle to a person born in the state of New-Jersey
column7: before its separation from the mother country
column8: we think it conclusive upon the point
column9: that the legislature of that state *213 by the most unequivocal declarations
column10: asserted its right to the allegiance of such of its citizens as had left the state
column11: and had attempted to return to their former allegiance.

column3: contains an express declaration that all such persons were subjects of the state
column4: who had been seduced by the enemy from their allegiance. The law speaks of them as jugitives not as aliens
column5: and they are invited
column6: not to become subjects
column7: but to return to their duty
column8: which the legislature clearly considered as still subsisting and obligatory upon them.

column1: The inquiry which the jury is directed to make
column2: by the act of the 18th of April
column4: in order to lay a foundation for the confiscation of the personal estates of these fugitives is
column5: whether the person had
column6: between the 4th of October
column8: and the 5th of June
column10: joined the armies of the king of Great Britain
column11: or otherwise offended against the form of his allegiance to the state. The 7th section of this law is peculiarly important
column12: because it provides not only for past cases
column13: which had occurred since the 5th of June
column15: but for all future cases
column16: and in all of them
column17: the inquiry is to be whether the offender has joined the armies of the king
column18: or otherwise offended against the form of his allegiance to the state.

column2: the real estates of these persons remained vested in them; and when by the law of the 11th of December
column4: the legislature thought proper to act upon this part of their property
column5: it was declared to be forfeited for their offences
column6: not escheatable on the ground of alienage. This last act is particularly entitled to attention
column7: as it contains a legislative declaration of the point of time
column8: when the right of election to adhere to the old allegiance ceased
column9: and the duties of allegiance to the new government commenced. Those who joined the enemy between the 19th of April
column11: and the 4th of October
column13: (when an express declaration upon the subject was made
column14: ) and who had not since returned and become subjects in allegiance to the new government
column15: by taking the oaths of abjuration and allegiance
column16: are pronounced guilty of high treason
column17: not for the purpose of affecting them personally
column18: which would have *214 been most unjust; but with a view to the confiscation of their estates. And consistent with this distinction
column19: the jury are to inquire in respect to these persons
column20: not as in the case of those who had left the state after the 4th of October
column22: whether they had offended against the form of their allegiance
column23: but
column24: whether they are offenders within this act
column25: that is
column26: by having joined the enemy between the 19th of April
column28: and the 4th of October
column30: and not having returned and become subjects in allegiance to the state.

column1: Having taken this view of the laws of New-Jersey upon this subject
column2: it may safely be asserted that prior to the treaty of peace
column3: it would not have been competent
column4: even for that state to allege alienage in Daniel Coxe in the face of repeated declarations of the legitimate authority of the government
column5: that he continued to owe allegiance to the state
column6: notwithstanding all his attempts to throw it off. If he was an alien
column7: he must have been so by the laws of New-Jersey; but those laws had uniformly asserted
column8: that he was an offender against the form of his allegiance to the state. How then can this court
column9: acting upon the laws of New-Jersey declare him an alien? The conclusion is inevitable
column10: that
column11: prior to the treaty of peace
column12: Daniel Coxe was entitled to hold
column13: and had a capacity to take lands in New-Jersey by descent.

column1: But it is insisted that the treaty of peace
column2: operating upon his condition at that time
column3: or afterwards
column4: he became an alien to the state of New-Jersey in consequence of his election
column5: then made to become a subject of the king
column6: and his subsequent conduct confirming that election. In vain have we searched that instrument for some clause or expression
column7: which by any implication could work this effect.

column1: It contains an acknowledgment of the independence and sovereignty of the United States
column2: in their political capacities
column3: and a relinquishment on the part of his Britannic majesty
column4: of all claim to the government
column5: propriety and territorial rights of the same. These concessions amounted
column6: no doubt
column7: to a formal renunciation of all claim to the allegiance of the citizens of the United States. But the question who were at that period citizens of the *215 is not decided
column8: or in the slightest degree alluded to in this instrument; it was left necessarily to depend upon the laws of the respective states
column9: who in their sovereign capacities had acted authoritatively upon the subject. It left all such persons in the situation it found them
column10: neither making those citizens
column11: who had by the laws of any of the states been declared aliens
column12: nor releasing from their allegiance
column13: any who had become
column14: and were claimed as citizens. It repeals no laws of any of the states which were then in force
column15: and operating upon this subject
column16: but on the contrary it recognises their validity by stipulating that congress should recommend to the states
column17: the reconsideration of such of them as had worked confiscations. If the laws relating to this subject were at that period
column18: in the language of one of the counsel
column19: temporary and functi officio
column20: they certainly were not rendered so by the terms of the treaty
column21: nor by the political situation of the two nations
column22: in consequence of it. A contrary doctrine is not only inconsistent with the sovereignties of the states
column23: anterior to
column24: and independant of the treaty
column25: but its indiscriminate adoption might be productive of more mischief than it is possible for us to foresee.

column1: If then at the period of the treaty
column2: the laws of New-Jersey which had made Daniel Coxe a subject of that state were in full force
column3: and were not repealed
column4: or in any manner affected by that instrument
column5: if by force of these laws he was incapable of throwing off his allegiance to the state
column6: and derived no right to do so by virtue of the treaty
column7: it follows that he still retains the capacity which he possessed before the treaty
column8: to take lands by descent in New-Jersey
column9: and consequently that the lessor of the plaintiff is entitled to recover.

in ordinary cases. But the bankrupt law changes essentially the relative situation of the parties; and the provisions making that change are thought, by a majority of the court, to have a material influence on the words of the 42d section of the act, which provide for the case of mutual debts and credits.

It is the opinion of the court that this is a debt, which might have been proved under the 6th section of the act. It is a debt, which, by a suit against both the partners, might have been recovered against either of them, and either might have been compelled to pay the whole. Although due from the company, yet it is also due from each member of the company; and the claim of the creditor for its satisfaction extended, previous to the act of bankruptcy, to the whole property of each member of the firm, as well as to the joint property of the firm. It would be certainly impairing that claim to apply, by the operation of law, the whole particular fund to other creditors, who, at the time of the bankruptcy, had not a better legal claim on that fund than the Tuckers, without allowing them to participate in it. The court, therefore, would be much inclined to consider the creditors of the partnership as having a right, under the general description of creditors of the bankrupt, to prove their debts before the commissioners. But all doubt on this subject seems to be removed by the proviso to the 34th section. That section declares, that the bankrupt shall be discharged from all debts which were due from him at the date of the bankruptcy, and all which were or might have been proved under the said commission, Provided that no such discharge of a bankrupt shall release or discharge any person
column7: who was a partner with such bankrupt at the time he or she became bankrupt

column9: from which such bankrupt was discharged as aforesaid."

This exposition of the bankrupt act appears to the court to conform to that which is given in England. As the bankrupt law of the United States, so far as respects this case, is almost, if not completely, copied from that of England, the decisions which have been made on that law by the English judges may be considered as having been adopted with the text they expounded.

If the legislatures of the several states may, at will, annul the judgments of the courts of the United States, and destroy the rights acquired under those judgments, the constitution itself becomes a solemn mockery; and the nation is deprived of the means of enforcing its laws by the instrumentality of its own tribunals. So fatal a result must be deprecated by all; and the people of Pennsylvania, not less than the citizens of every other state, must feel a deep interest in resisting principles so destructive of the union, and in averting consequences so fatal to themselves.

The act in question does not, in terms, assert the universal right of the state to interpose in every case whatever; but assigns, as a motive for its interposition in this particular case, that the sentence, the execution of which it prohibits, was rendered, in a cause over which the federal courts have no jurisdiction.

If the ultimate right to determine the jurisdiction of the courts of the union is placed by the constitution in the several state legislatures, then this act concludes the subject; but if that power necessarily resides in the supreme judicial tribunal of the nation, then the jurisdiction of the district court of Pennsylvania, over the case in which that jurisdiction was exercised, ought to be most deliberately examined; and the act of Pennsylvania, with whatever respect it may be considered, cannot be permitted to prejudice the question.

column6: in not performing an act which the law does not pronounce necessary to his title

column1: If the omission to record the survey in two months would avoid it
column2: then the omission of any other act enjoined by the same section would equally avoid it. The surveyor is directed to see the land "plainly bounded by natural bounds
column3: or marked trees." Has his conforming to this direction ever been inquired into
column4: in a contest respecting the validity of a survey? Would any gentleman of the bar contend that the land was not plainly bounded
column5: and that
column6: for this reason
column7: a survey actually made was void? He is
column8: within five months
column9: to deliver to his employer a plat and certificate. Suppose six months should elapse before he complies with this duty
column10: is the survey void? He is to certify the true quantity of land contained in the survey. Would the gentlemen from Kentucky be willing to adopt it as a principle that every survey expressing a quantity more or less than the true quantity is absolutely void? He is to state the water-courses
column11: and also the plantations next adjoining. Should any one of these be omitted
column12: is the survey void? He is to return a list of surveys in the month of June annually to the clerk's office. Should he fail in this
column13: are the surveys void? On these points it is impossible seriously to insist; and the court can perceive no distinction between them. They are all merely directory to the officer
column14: and none of them affect a title which commenced before they are to be performed. He is subjected to a penalty for failing in any one of these duties
column15: but his performing or omitting them is unimportant to the rights of those for whom surveys have been made.

column35: whether founded in error or truth

column1: *165 The first question depends upon the construction which the court may give to the 4th section of the statute of Virginia

which declares that all conveyances of land, marriage settlements of lands, slaves, or other personal property, deeds of trust and mortgages thereafter made should be void as to all creditors and subsequent purchasers, unless the same were acknowledged or proved, and recorded within the time prescribed by the statute; but that the same as between the parties and their heirs should nevertheless be valid and binding.

The deed from Rebecca Kenner, the defendant in error, previous to her intermarriage with Charles Turner, by which the slaves in question were settled on the said Charles Turner and herself, during their lives, and the life of the longest liver of them, with remainder to the heirs of the said Rebecca, not having been proved and recorded within the time prescribed by law, it is contended by the plaintiff in error that the same became void as to the creditors of Charles Turner, whose rights remained unimpaired by that deed, in the same manner as if it had never been made; in which case, it is not denied that an absolute estate would have vested in the husband, on his marriage.

This argument proceeds upon the ground, that by the words all creditors and subsequent purchasers
column6: is meant as well the creditors of the grantee and subsequent purchasers from him, as those who might derive title under the grantor. Although the words are certainly broad enough to comprehend the whole, it is believed by a majority of the court that the construction should be such as to limit the application of them to the creditors of, and subsequent purchasers from, the grantor. In no case but one, where a title can be set up for the grantee paramount the deed, can it ever be the interest of a creditor of the grantee to insist upon such a construction as is contended for in this; for as he must derive his title *166 under the deed
column7: if it be void as to him

column9: whose only title is under the deed. It would be strange that a deed should be binding upon the grantee and his heirs

column11: for a valuable consideration; and yet such would be the consequence

column1: I will not contest the general principle

column1: What was the object of the legislature? It was to protect the community from that false credit which men acquire in society

Her creditors before marriage become his during coverture; she can contract no debts to which she can be made personally liable; her personal property becomes his by the act of intermarriage

column1: That the court as a court of chancery has jurisdiction of such cases
column2: is a point established by a long course of practice in Virginia and in Kentucky; but in the exercise of that jurisdiction
column3: it will proceed according to the principles of equity. In such case
column4: a prior entry will be considered as notice to him *221 who has the legal title
column5: if such entry be sufficiently certain. And the legal title will be considered as holden for him who has the prior equity.

column2: Ch. J. delivered the opinion of the court as follows:

column1: This is an appeal from a decree of the court for the district of Kentucky
column2: by which Taylor was directed to convey to Bodley and others a part of a tract of land to which he held an elder patent
column3: but to which Bodley and others claim the better right under a junior patent. The judge of the district court having directed such part of the land held by Taylor to be conveyed to Bodley and others
column4: as appeared by certain rules
column5: which he has applied to the case
column6: to be within their claim
column7: and not within Taylor's location

column1: Previous to any discussion of the rights of the parties
column2: it has become necessary to dispose of a preliminary question.

column1: The defendant in the court below objects to the jurisdiction of a court of equity
column2: and contends not only that the present case furnishes no ground of jurisdiction
column3: upon general principles
column4: but that the land law under which both titles originate
column5: in giving a remedy by which rights under entries might be decided previous to the emanation of a patent
column6: has prohibited an examination of the same question after a patent shall have issued.

column1: Had this been a case of the first impression
column2: some contrariety of opinion would perhaps have existed on this point. But it has been sufficiently shown that the practice of resorting to a court of chancery in order to set up an equitable against the legal title
column3: received
column4: in its origin
column5: the sanction of the court of appeals
column6: *222 while Kentucky remained a part of Virginia
column7: and has been so confirmed by an uninterrupted series of decisions as to be incorporated into their system
column8: and to be taken into view in the consideration of every title to lands in that country. Such a principle cannot now be shaken.

column1: But it is an inquiry of vast importance whether
column2: in deciding claims of this description
column3: a court of equity acts upon its known
column4: established and general principles
column5: or is merely substituted for a court of law
column6: with power to decide questions respecting rights under the statute
column7: as they existed previous to the consummation of those rights by patent.

column1: It has been argued that the right acquired by an entry is a legal right
column2: because it is given by a statute
column3: that it is the statutory inception of a legal title which gives to the person making it a right
column4: against every person not having a prior entry
column5: to obtain a patent and to hold the land. The inference drawn from this is
column6: that as the law affords no remedy against a person who has defeated this right by improperly obtaining a prior patent
column7: a court of chancery
column8: which can afford it
column9: ought to consider itself as sitting in the character of a court of law
column10: and ought to decide those questions as a court of law would decide them
column11: if capable of looking beyond the patent.

column1: This reasoning would perhaps be conclusive if a court of chancery was
column2: by statute
column3: substituted in the place of a court of law
column4: with an express grant of jurisdiction in the case. But the jurisdiction exercised by a court of chancery is not granted by statute; it is assumed by itself: and what can justify that assumption but the opinion that cases of this description come within the sphere of its general action? In all cases in which a court of equity takes jurisdiction
column5: it will exercise that jurisdiction upon its own principles. It is believed that no exception to this rule is to be found in the books
column6: and the state of land titles in Kentucky is not believed to furnish one. The true ground of the jurisdiction *223 of a court of equity is
column7: that an entry is considered as a record of which a subsequent locator may have notice
column8: and therefore must be presumed to have it; consequently
column9: although he may obtain the first patent
column10: he is liable
column11: in equity
column12: to the rules which apply to a subsequent purchaser with notice of a prior equitable right. This certainly brings the validity of the entries before the court
column13: but it also brings with that question every other which defeats the equity of the plaintiff.

column2: therefore
column3: will entertain jurisdiction of the cause
column4: but will exercise that jurisdiction in conformity with the settled principles of a court of chancery. It will afford a remedy which a court of law cannot afford
column5: but since that remedy is not given by statute
column6: it will be applied by this court as the principles of equity require its application.

column1: Neither is the compact between Virginia and Kentucky considered as affecting this case.
If the same measure of justice be meted to the citizens of each state

column8:
&c.

The only objection to this entry is, that the beginning is uncertain.

Were the validity of this objection to be admitted, it would shake almost every title in Kentucky. If it be recollected that almost every acre of good land in that state was located at a time when only a few individuals, collected in scattered forts or villages, encroached on the rights of the savages and wild beasts of the country, that neither these sparse settlers, nor those hardy adventurers who travelled thither in quest of lands, could venture out to explore the country, without exposing their lives to imminent hazard, that many of those who had thus explored the country, and who made locations, were unlettered men, not only incapable of expounding the laws, but some of them incapable of reading, it is not wonderful that the courts of Kentucky should have relaxed, in some degree, the rigour of the rule requiring an impracticable precision in making entries, should have laid hold of every circumstance which might afford that certainty which the law has required, and should be content with that reasonable certainty which would enable a subsequent locator, by the exercise of a due degree of judgment and diligence, to locate his own lands on the adjacent residuum.

The entry of Crutcher and Tibbs possesses this reasonable certainty.

The blue licks was a place of general notoriety, and there appears to have been no difficulty in ascertaining the point from which the mensuration should commence. There being only one of the three roads leading from that point, which ran nearly a N.E. course, no subsequent locator could doubt on which road this land was placed. The entry having called for visible objects on the road about *225 seven miles from the licks
column9: those visible objects might be discovered without any extraordinary exertion; and if they could not be discovered

column14: and it appears that no difficulty has arisen

column3: shall
column4: besides the jurisdiction herein before granted

column9: in the same manner as from other district courts to their respective circuit courts.' And by the 21st section it is enacted
column10: 'that from final decrees in a district court in causes of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction
column11: where the matter in dispute exceeds the sum or value of three hundred dollars

column14: that all such appeals from final decrees as aforesaid
column15: from the district court of Maine
column16: shall be made to the circuit court
column17: next to be holden after each appeal
column18: in the district of Massachusetts.'

column4: 'that from all final judgments or decrees rendered or to be rendered in any circuit court
column5: or in any district court

column9: and of prize or no prize
column10: an appeal
column11: where the matter in dispute
